Context.Right: The first reason why education and preventative measures should receive a greater budget is the potential improvements in health system. I believe that decreasing the number of patients in the health system can lead hospitals and healthcare centers to be managed effectively which will result in better treatments for current patients. Therefore, society should be educated and became aware of health issues so that the potential precautions on the way of illnesses can be taken instead of trying to provide treatment for the increasing number of patients.

Prompt.Prompt0: Explain how education and preventative measures can decrease the number of patients in the health system.
Prompt.Prompt1: Provide some examples of health issues that can be prevented by education and awareness.
Prompt.Prompt2: Discuss the benefits of prevention for both individuals and society as a whole.
Prompt.Prompt3: Add a connecting paragraph that summarizes the main points of your argument and introduces the counter-argument.
Prompt.Prompt4: Acknowledge the possible limitations or challenges of implementing education and preventative measures in the health system.
Prompt.Prompt6: Write a paragraph to connect the left text and right text.
Prompt.Prompt7: Insert a passage connecting the two passages

Outcome.Outcome0: One of the main benefits of allocating more funds to education and preventative measures is that they can reduce the burden on the health system by decreasing the number of patients who need treatment. by raising awareness and promoting healthy behaviors, such as vaccination, nutrition, exercise, and hygiene, society can prevent many diseases and complications that would otherwise require hospitalization or medication. for example, educating people about the risks of smoking and offering them support to quit can lower the incidence of lung cancer, heart disease, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. similarly, teaching people how to manage their blood pressure, cholesterol, and diabetes can prevent strokes, heart attacks, and kidney failure. thus, education and preventative measures can not only improve the quality of life of individuals, but also free up resources and capacity in the health system for those who need them most.
Outcome.Outcome1: One way to educate and raise awareness of health issues is to provide information and campaigns on the causes and consequences of common and chronic diseases, such as diabetes, hypertension, cardiovascular problems, and cancer. these diseases can have a significant impact on the quality of life and the mortality of the patients, as well as on the costs and resources of the health system. however, many of them can be prevented or delayed by adopting healthy lifestyles, such as eating a balanced diet, exercising regularly, avoiding smoking and excessive alcohol consumption, and undergoing regular check-ups and screenings. by investing in education and preventative measures, society can reduce the risk factors and the incidence of these diseases, and therefore, improve the health outcomes and the efficiency of the health system.
Outcome.Outcome2: The left text argues that education and prevention should receive a greater budget because they can reduce the pressure on the health system and improve the quality of care for existing patients. however, the benefits of prevention are not only limited to the health sector, but also extend to the individuals and the society as a whole. the right text could elaborate on this point by providing some examples of how prevention can enhance the well-being, productivity, and social cohesion of people. for instance, prevention can help individuals avoid chronic diseases, disabilities, and premature deaths that can impair their physical and mental health, as well as their ability to work and participate in social activities. moreover, prevention can help society save resources, reduce inequalities, and promote solidarity among its members, as fewer people would need expensive and intensive treatments, more people would have access to quality health services, and more people would contribute to the common good. therefore, prevention is not only a cost-effective strategy, but also a moral and ethical duty for the society.
Outcome.Outcome3: In conclusion, i have argued that education and preventative measures are more beneficial for the society than spending more money on treatment. by investing in these areas, we can reduce the burden on the health system, improve the quality of care for existing patients, and prevent many diseases from occurring in the first place. however, some people may disagree with this view and claim that treatment is more urgent and effective than prevention. in the following paragraph, i will examine this counter-argument and explain why i think it is flawed.
Outcome.Outcome4: However, implementing education and preventative measures in the health system may not be easy or feasible in some contexts. for example, some communities may face barriers such as lack of access to reliable information, cultural beliefs, or socioeconomic factors that may limit their ability or willingness to adopt healthy behaviors or seek preventive services. moreover, some diseases or conditions may not be preventable or predictable, and may require urgent or specialized care that cannot be replaced by education or prevention. therefore, while education and preventative measures are important and beneficial, they should not be seen as the only or the best solution for all health problems, and they should be complemented by a robust and responsive health system that can meet the diverse and changing needs of the population.
Outcome.Outcome6: The left text argues that education and preventative measures should receive a greater budget than treatment because they can reduce the burden on the health system and improve the quality of care for existing patients. the right text supports this claim by explaining how educating society and raising awareness of health issues can help people avoid illnesses and take precautions that can prevent complications. thus, the right text provides an example of how education and prevention can benefit both individuals and the health system as a whole.
Outcome.Outcome7: One way to educate and prevent health issues is to promote healthy lifestyles and habits among the population. for example, encouraging people to exercise regularly, eat a balanced diet, avoid smoking and excessive alcohol consumption, and practice good hygiene can help prevent chronic diseases such as diabetes, heart disease, cancer, and obesity. these diseases are often costly and difficult to treat and can reduce the quality of life and productivity of the affected individuals. by investing more in education and prevention, the government can save money and resources in the long run and improve the overall well-being of the society. the first reason why education and preventative measures should receive a greater budget is the potential improvements in health system.

Context.Left: Universtiy is an entrance to life. It equips us with a package of wisdom and virtue to succeed. It is the importance of university that raises a question whether students with best scholastic performance deserve university study or just any young wishful people. Both sides are to be discussed before a conclusion is reached.

Outcome.Outcome0: The importance of university as an entrance to life can be seen from different perspectives. on the one hand, university provides a rigorous and systematic education that cultivates wisdom and virtue, which are essential for achieving success in various fields and professions. on the other hand, university also offers a rich and diverse environment that fosters artistic talent and enhances soft skills, such as creativity, communication, and teamwork. these aspects of university education can help young people to pursue their passion, express their individuality, and adapt to the changing demands of the society and the world. therefore, the question of who deserves university study is not only based on scholastic performance, but also on the aspirations and potentials of young people.
Outcome.Outcome1: University is an entrance to life. it equips us with a package of wisdom and virtue to succeed. for instance, through various courses and disciplines, university students can acquire knowledge and skills that are relevant to their chosen fields and careers. they can also learn to think critically, creatively, and ethically, as well as to communicate effectively and collaborate with others. moreover, university students can benefit from the exposure to diverse cultures, perspectives, and experiences that enrich their worldview and enhance their cultural sensitivity and tolerance. it is the importance of university that raises a question whether students with best scholastic performance deserve university study or just any young wishful people. both sides are to be discussed before a conclusion is reached. however, university is not just about academic studies but also a place to nurture artistic talent and develop soft skills. therefore, it should be up for grabs for a majority of young people, who wish to pursue their passion as well as develop comprehensively.
Outcome.Outcome2: On the one hand, some might argue that students with best scholastic performance deserve university study more than others, since they have proven their academic abilities and potential to excel in their chosen fields. they might also claim that university study is a competitive and demanding environment that requires high levels of intelligence, diligence and discipline, which only the top students can cope with. moreover, they might contend that allocating limited resources and opportunities to the most qualified students is fair and efficient, as it ensures the quality and reputation of the university and the society.
Outcome.Outcome3: Academic studies are undoubtedly a crucial part of university education, as they provide students with the knowledge and skills needed for their chosen fields of study and future careers. however, they are not the only criteria for university admission, nor the only benefits that university offers. this is because university is also a place to nurture artistic talent and develop soft skills, such as creativity, communication, teamwork, leadership, and critical thinking. these are essential for personal growth, cultural diversity, social responsibility, and innovation in a rapidly changing world. therefore, it should be up for grabs for a majority of young people, who wish to pursue their passion as well as develop comprehensively.
Outcome.Outcome4: Universtiy is an entrance to life. it equips us with a package of wisdom and virtue to succeed. it is the importance of university that raises a question whether students with best scholastic performance deserve university study or just any young wishful people. both sides are to be discussed before a conclusion is reached. on the one hand, some may argue that university study should be reserved for the most academically gifted students, who can contribute to the advancement of knowledge and society. on the other hand, however, university is not just about academic studies but also a place to nurture artistic talent and develop soft skills. therefore, it should be up for grabs for a majority of young people, who wish to pursue their passion as well as develop comprehensively. this view suggests that university education is not only a privilege but also a right and a responsibility for the younger generation.
Outcome.Outcome5: Some people might argue that university study should be reserved for students with the best scholastic performance, since it is an entrance to life that equips them with a package of wisdom and virtue to succeed. they might claim that academic excellence is the key criterion to select the most deserving candidates for higher education, and that limited resources and opportunities should not be wasted on those who are less capable or motivated. however, this view overlooks another aspect of university education, which is not just about academic studies but also a place to nurture artistic talent and develop soft skills.
Outcome.Outcome7: On the one hand, some people may argue that university study is a privilege that should be reserved for the most outstanding students, who have proven their academic excellence and potential through rigorous exams and assessments. they may claim that university education is a scarce and valuable resource that should be allocated to those who can make the most of it and contribute to the advancement of knowledge and society. they may also contend that admitting students with lower academic standards would lower the quality of education and dilute the reputation of the institution.

Context.Right: One of the strong arguments in favour of tighter media control is to limit the violent and sexual content. They have a serious impact on people in their puberty. For example, an internet cartoon comedy called happy tree is extremely brutal, where the characters usually have their heads or limbs tear off. Another supporting reason is that television companies import foreign programmes from time to time and audiences might accept their ideas which maybe otherwise not welcomed to local culture. A few years ago there was a Japanese game show which involved throwing cream cakes to the loser. This is actually very environmentally unfriendly.

Prompt.Prompt0: Introduce the topic of media control and state your position on it.
Prompt.Prompt1: Explain why violent and sexual content can have a serious impact on people in their puberty and provide some evidence or examples.
Prompt.Prompt2: Elaborate on the negative effects of foreign programmes on local culture and values and give some specific instances.

Outcome.Outcome0: Media control is a controversial issue that has sparked debates among different groups of society. some people believe that the media should have more freedom to express diverse views and entertain audiences, while others argue that the media should be regulated more strictly to protect public morals and values. in this essay, i will support the latter view and explain why tighter media control is necessary and beneficial.
Outcome.Outcome1: One of the strong arguments in favour of tighter media control is to limit the violent and sexual content. they can have a serious impact on people in their puberty, who are undergoing physical and psychological changes and are more susceptible to external influences. for instance, some studies have shown that exposure to violent media can increase aggression, desensitization, and fear in young people, while sexual media can affect their sexual attitudes, behaviours, and expectations. an internet cartoon comedy called happy tree is extremely brutal, where the characters usually have their heads or limbs tear off. such a programme can distort the reality of violence and its consequences, and may encourage imitation or indifference. another supporting reason is that television companies import foreign programmes from time to time and audiences might accept their ideas which maybe otherwise not welcomed to local culture. a few years ago there was a japanese game show which involved throwing cream cakes to the loser. this is actually very environmentally unfriendly.
Outcome.Outcome2: The left text argues that tighter media control is needed to limit the violent and sexual content of the media, which can have a harmful influence on young people. the right text further supports this claim by pointing out that some foreign programmes that are imported by television companies may also pose a threat to the local culture and values of the audiences. for instance, some foreign programmes may promote materialism, consumerism, individualism, or other ideologies that are incompatible with the traditional or religious beliefs of the local community. some foreign programmes may also ridicule or stereotype the local customs, history, or identity, or show disrespect or ignorance towards the local issues or challenges. such programmes may erode the sense of belonging, pride, or solidarity of the local people, or create conflicts or misunderstandings among different groups. therefore, the author suggests that tighter media control is necessary to protect the local culture and values from the negative effects of foreign programmes.
Outcome.Outcome3: These are some of the reasons why some people advocate for more regulation of the media, especially in terms of the violence and sexual content that can influence young minds and behaviour. they believe that the media should be more responsible and respectful of the local values and norms, and not expose the audience to harmful or inappropriate messages. however, not everyone agrees with this view. there are also arguments that favour more freedom and diversity in the media, and that challenge the assumptions and effects of media control.
Outcome.Outcome4: However, some might argue that tighter media control is unnecessary and even harmful to the freedom of expression and diversity of opinions. they might claim that viewers have the right to choose what they want to watch and that they can distinguish between reality and fiction. they might also contend that foreign programmes can enrich the local culture and foster mutual understanding and respect. these arguments, however, are not convincing enough. firstly, not all viewers, especially children and adolescents, have the ability or the guidance to filter out the negative influences of violent and sexual content. they might imitate or internalize what they see and develop aggressive or irresponsible behaviours. secondly, not all foreign programmes are beneficial or appropriate for the local culture. some might contain offensive or misleading messages that could undermine the values and identity of the local society. therefore, tighter media control is justified and necessary to protect the public interest and morality.
Outcome.Outcome5: However, not everyone agrees that tighter media control is necessary or beneficial. opponents of this view argue that media consumers have the right to choose what they want to watch or read, and that censorship violates their freedom of expression and creativity. they also point out that media content can be educational, entertaining, or inspiring, and that exposure to different cultures and perspectives can broaden one's horizons and promote tolerance. for instance, a japanese game show that involved throwing cream cakes to the loser might seem wasteful and disrespectful, but it could also be seen as a humorous and harmless way of having fun and relieving stress.
Outcome.Outcome7: However, not everyone agrees that tighter media control is necessary or beneficial. some opponents argue that media consumers have the right to choose what they want to watch or read, and that censorship violates their freedom of expression and creativity. they also point out that media violence and sexuality are not the main causes of social problems, and that other factors, such as education, family, and peer influence, play a more important role in shaping people's behaviour and attitudes. moreover, they claim that exposure to foreign programmes can also have positive effects, such as enhancing cultural diversity and awareness, and stimulating curiosity and learning. for instance, the japanese game show mentioned above could also be seen as a humorous and harmless way of entertaining the audience and the participants.

Context.Left: As illustrated before, several other solutions can be introduced to assist in reducing pollution and traffic problems. Primarily, authorities should spare no efforts in improving public transportation facilities, such as constructing more bus lines, in order to reducing the usage of private cars. Furthermore, temporarily targets should be set, with regard to the limitations of pollutants in a certain period of time, for example, a season. Plus with supervisory institutions built to find and address problems. Meanwhile, cultivating a sense of environmental protection would also work out, though it might not be into effect immediately, but in the long run, it would be a wise choice.

Prompt.Prompt0: Introduce the topic of pollution and traffic problems and state your main argument in a clear thesis statement.
Prompt.Prompt1: Provide some background information on the causes and effects of pollution and traffic problems, and cite some relevant statistics or examples to support your claims.
Prompt.Prompt2: Explain how improving public transportation facilities can reduce the usage of private cars and thus lower the emissions of pollutants and the congestion of roads.
Prompt.Prompt3: Discuss how setting temporary targets and establishing supervisory institutions can help monitor and regulate the levels of pollutants and ensure the compliance of environmental policies.
Prompt.Prompt4: Summarize the main points of your argument and restate your thesis in a different way. Also, suggest some possible ways to cultivate a sense of environmental protection among the public and the benefits of doing so.

Outcome.Outcome0: Pollution and traffic problems are two of the most pressing challenges that many cities face nowadays. they not only affect the health and well-being of the residents, but also harm the natural environment and the economic development. therefore, it is essential to find effective and feasible solutions to tackle these issues and improve the urban quality of life. in this essay, i will argue that authorities should take a comprehensive and proactive approach that involves enhancing public transportation, setting and enforcing pollution standards, and raising environmental awareness. as illustrated before, several other solutions can be introduced to assist in reducing pollution and traffic problems. primarily, authorities should spare no efforts in improving public transportation facilities, such as constructing more bus lines, in order to reducing the usage of private cars. furthermore, temporary targets should be set, with regard to the limitations of pollutants in a certain period of time, for example, a season. plus with supervisory institutions built to find and address problems. meanwhile, cultivating a sense of environmental protection would also work out, though it might not be into effect immediately, but in the long run, it would be a wise choice.
Outcome.Outcome1: Pollution and traffic problems are serious issues that affect the health and well-being of millions of people around the world. according to the world health organization, air pollution alone causes about 7 million premature deaths every year, and contributes to climate change, acid rain, and ozone depletion. moreover, traffic congestion wastes time, energy, and money, and increases the risk of accidents, noise, and stress. some of the main causes of these problems are the rapid urbanization, industrialization, and population growth, which have led to a high demand for transportation, energy, and resources, and a lack of adequate planning, regulation, and management. therefore, it is urgent and necessary to find effective and sustainable solutions to address these challenges and improve the quality of life for current and future generations. as illustrated before, several other solutions can be introduced to assist in reducing pollution and traffic problems. primarily, authorities should spare no efforts in improving public transportation facilities, such as constructing more bus lines, in order to reducing the usage of private cars. furthermore, temporarily targets should be set, with regard to the limitations of pollutants in a certain period of time, for example, a season. plus with supervisory institutions built to find and address problems. meanwhile, cultivating a sense of environmental protection would also work out, though it might not be into effect immediately, but in the long run, it would be a wise choice.
Outcome.Outcome2: One of the most effective ways to tackle the pollution and traffic issues is to enhance the quality and accessibility of public transportation facilities. by building more bus lines, expanding subway networks, and providing convenient and affordable fares, authorities can encourage more people to choose public transport over private cars. this can not only reduce the demand for parking spaces and the consumption of fossil fuels, but also lower the emissions of pollutants that harm the environment and human health. moreover, by easing the congestion of roads, public transport can also save time and money for commuters and improve the efficiency of urban mobility. therefore, improving public transportation facilities can be a win-win solution for both the environment and the society.
Outcome.Outcome3: As illustrated before, several other solutions can be introduced to assist in reducing pollution and traffic problems. primarily, authorities should spare no efforts in improving public transportation facilities, such as constructing more bus lines, in order to reducing the usage of private cars. furthermore, temporarily targets should be set, with regard to the limitations of pollutants in a certain period of time, for example, a season. setting temporary targets can help motivate and measure the progress of environmental improvement and provide feedback and incentives for the stakeholders involved. additionally, supervisory institutions should be built to find and address problems. these institutions can help monitor and regulate the levels of pollutants and ensure the compliance of environmental policies. they can also enforce penalties and rewards for the violators and performers of the standards and rules. moreover, they can provide guidance and support for the public and private sectors to adopt greener practices and technologies. meanwhile, cultivating a sense of environmental protection would also work out, though it might not be into effect immediately, but in the long run, it would be a wise choice.
Outcome.Outcome4: To conclude, pollution and traffic problems are serious issues that affect the quality of life and health of urban residents. they require comprehensive and coordinated solutions from the authorities, the public and the private sectors. improving public transportation, setting temporary targets for pollution reduction and establishing supervisory institutions are some of the effective measures that can be taken to address these problems. however, these measures alone are not enough. it is also essential to raise the awareness and responsibility of the public towards the environment and encourage them to adopt more sustainable and eco-friendly lifestyles. this can be done through education, campaigns, incentives and regulations that promote environmental values and behaviors. by doing so, not only can the current problems be alleviated, but also the future generations can inherit a cleaner and greener planet.
Outcome.Outcome5: To achieve these solutions, however, it is essential to have the cooperation and participation of various stakeholders, such as the government, the public, and the private sector. the government should not only provide adequate funding and policy support for the public transportation and environmental protection projects, but also enforce strict regulations and penalties for those who violate the emission standards or cause environmental damage. the public should also take responsibility for their own travel choices and consumption habits, and adopt more eco-friendly and energy-efficient alternatives whenever possible. the private sector, especially the industries and businesses that contribute to the pollution and traffic problems, should also implement green practices and innovations, such as using renewable energy sources, recycling waste materials, and optimizing production processes. by working together, these actors can create a more sustainable and livable urban environment for themselves and future generations.
Outcome.Outcome7: These solutions, however, may not be sufficient to tackle the root causes of pollution and traffic problems. in order to achieve a more sustainable and livable urban environment, some fundamental changes are also needed in the way people plan, design, and manage the city. the following passage will discuss some of these changes and how they can benefit the city and its residents.

Outcome.Outcome0: Studying in many subjects not only helps students to explore their interests and talents, but also prepares them for the challenges and opportunities of the modern world. by learning different skills and knowledge, students can develop their critical thinking, creativity, communication, and collaboration abilities, which are essential for the 21st century. moreover, studying in many subjects exposes students to diverse perspectives and cultures, which can broaden their horizons and foster their respect and appreciation for others. these benefits can enhance their personal and professional growth, as well as their contribution to society.

Outcome.Outcome0: However, not everyone agrees that zoos are beneficial for animals and humans. the opponents of zoos argue that keeping animals in captivity is cruel and unethical, as it deprives them of their natural freedom, behaviors and social interactions. they also claim that zoos are not effective in conserving wildlife, as they often breed animals for commercial purposes, neglect their welfare and health, and expose them to stress and diseases. moreover, they challenge the educational value of zoos, as they suggest that zoos present a distorted and unrealistic image of animals and their habitats, and that people can learn more about animals from documentaries, books and other sources. therefore, they propose that zoos should be replaced by sanctuaries, reserves and other alternatives that respect the rights and needs of animals.
Outcome.Outcome1: However, not everyone agrees that zoos are beneficial for animals and humans. some critics argue that keeping animals in captivity is unethical and harmful to their physical and mental health. they claim that zoos deprive animals of their natural behaviors, social interactions and freedom of movement. they also point out that zoos often expose animals to stress, boredom, loneliness and diseases. moreover, they question the educational and conservation value of zoos, as they believe that zoos do not teach people to respect animals or their habitats, but rather to view them as objects of entertainment and curiosity. they suggest that zoos should be replaced by more humane alternatives, such as wildlife sanctuaries, rehabilitation centers and ecotourism. therefore, these critics oppose the existence of zoos.
Outcome.Outcome2: However, the opponents of zoos argue that keeping animals in captivity is cruel and unethical. they claim that zoos deprive animals of their natural behaviors, social interactions and freedom of movement. animals in zoos often suffer from stress, boredom, loneliness and health problems due to the artificial and confined environment. moreover, zoos do not always educate the public about the true needs and characteristics of animals, but rather display them as objects of entertainment and profit. some critics also doubt the effectiveness of zoos in conserving wildlife, as they often prioritize the popular and profitable species over the less attractive and endangered ones. therefore, zoos are seen as a violation of animal rights and welfare.
Outcome.Outcome3: However, keeping animals in captivity is not without ethical, environmental and health issues. some critics argue that zoos deprive animals of their natural rights and freedoms, and subject them to unnatural and stressful conditions. they claim that zoos cannot replicate the complexity and diversity of the wild habitats, and that animals suffer from boredom, frustration, isolation and disease. moreover, some zoos may exploit animals for profit or entertainment, and neglect their welfare and conservation. additionally, zoos may have negative impacts on the environment, such as generating waste, consuming resources, and disrupting ecosystems. therefore, zoos should be held accountable for their ethical and environmental responsibilities, and ensure that animals are treated with respect and care.
Outcome.Outcome4: However, not everyone agrees that zoos are harmful to animals or to the environment. there are also some positive aspects of keeping animals in captivity that should be considered. in fact, some people argue that zoos have many benefits for both the animals and the humans who visit them. the following paragraph will explore some of the main arguments in favor of zoos.
Outcome.Outcome6: However, not everyone agrees with the idea of keeping animals in zoos. some critics argue that zoos are unnatural, cruel and unethical. they claim that zoos deprive animals of their freedom, dignity and natural behaviors. they also point out that zoos often fail to provide adequate space, enrichment, health care and social interaction for the animals. moreover, they question the effectiveness of zoos in conservation and education. they suggest that zoos may actually harm the wildlife by promoting the idea that animals are commodities, objects or spectacles. they also doubt that zoos can teach people to respect and appreciate animals, when they are displayed in artificial and often stressful conditions. therefore, they propose that zoos should be replaced by more humane alternatives, such as wildlife sanctuaries, reserves or rehabilitation centers.

Context.Left: Moreover, capital punishment curbs the inspiration and prospects of other hateful crimes. When a criminal mind knows the quantum of punishment, they will fear and not commit such crimes. Thus, the rate of crime and violence is effectively decreased.
Context.Right: However, the jury giving the verdict are also humans. They have the life of a person at their discretion. They can make mistakes which can sometimes affect an innocent, circumstantially marred criminals. The jury must therefore, take into account the circumstances of committing a crime. For example, if an individual murders someone for self-defense, then such a crime is not heinous. Only deserving criminals, who commit such hateful crimes in their proper senses are subjected to capital punishment.

Prompt.Prompt1: Explain how capital punishment can deter other potential criminals and reduce the crime rate in the second paragraph.
Prompt.Prompt2: Add a counterargument that acknowledges the possibility of human error and injustice in the jury system in the third paragraph.
Prompt.Prompt3: Elaborate on the difference between heinous and non-heinous crimes and how they should be treated differently in the fourth paragraph.

Outcome.Outcome0: Capital punishment, or the death penalty, is one of the most controversial and debated issues in the criminal justice system. it is the ultimate sanction for the most serious and heinous crimes, such as murder, rape, terrorism, and treason. supporters of capital punishment argue that it serves as a deterrent, a retribution, and a safeguard for society. opponents of capital punishment contend that it is immoral, ineffective, and prone to error. in this essay, i will examine the arguments for and against capital punishment, and the implications of its use.
Outcome.Outcome1: Capital punishment can have a deterrent effect on other potential criminals who may be contemplating committing heinous crimes. by imposing the ultimate penalty for the most serious offenses, the state sends a clear message that such acts will not be tolerated and will be met with swift and severe justice. this can create a fear of the consequences and a sense of moral responsibility among the potential offenders, who may refrain from engaging in violent and immoral behavior. thus, capital punishment can reduce the crime rate by preventing some crimes from happening in the first place.
Outcome.Outcome2: Moreover, capital punishment curbs the inspiration and prospects of other hateful crimes. when a criminal mind knows the quantum of punishment, they will fear and not commit such crimes. thus, the rate of crime and violence is effectively decreased. however, some opponents of capital punishment argue that it is not a fair and reliable system of justice. they claim that the jury giving the verdict are also humans. they can make mistakes which can sometimes affect an innocent, circumstantially marred criminals. they point out the cases of wrongful convictions, racial bias, and arbitrariness in the application of the death penalty. they contend that capital punishment violates the principles of human dignity, equality, and due process of law. the jury must therefore, take into account the circumstances of committing a crime. for example, if an individual murders someone for self-defense, then such a crime is not heinous. only deserving criminals, who commit such hateful crimes in their proper senses are subjected to capital punishment.
Outcome.Outcome3: The left text argues that capital punishment is a deterrent for heinous crimes, which are those that involve extreme cruelty, depravity, or malice. such crimes, according to this view, deserve the ultimate penalty of death, as they violate the basic values of humanity and justice. the right text, on the other hand, cautions against the possibility of error and injustice in the judicial system, which can lead to the execution of innocent or mitigated offenders. such offenders may have committed non-heinous crimes, which are those that do not involve the same degree of moral turpitude or harm as heinous crimes. for example, a non-heinous crime may be motivated by self-defense, necessity, or provocation, which can reduce the culpability or responsibility of the offender. therefore, the right text suggests that the jury should consider the circumstances of each case and apply capital punishment only to the most deserving and dangerous criminals.
Outcome.Outcome4: Both sides of the debate on capital punishment have valid arguments. supporters of the death penalty argue that it deters other criminals from committing heinous crimes and serves justice to the victims and society. opponents of the death penalty contend that it is prone to human error and injustice, and that it does not account for the circumstances and motives of the offenders. therefore, the jury should be careful and fair in deciding who deserves to die and who does not. in my opinion, capital punishment is a harsh and irreversible measure that should be reserved for the most extreme and rare cases of evil and violence. i believe that there are alternative ways of punishing and rehabilitating criminals that respect human dignity and rights.
Outcome.Outcome5: One of the arguments in favor of capital punishment is that it deters other potential offenders from committing heinous crimes. by imposing the ultimate penalty, the justice system sends a clear message that such acts will not be tolerated. however, this argument also raises the question of fairness and accuracy in the judicial process. the jury who decides the fate of the accused are human beings who can make errors or be influenced by biases. therefore, they should carefully consider the context and motive of each crime and not apply the death penalty indiscriminately. for instance, a person who kills in self-defense should not be equated with a cold-blooded murderer.
Outcome.Outcome7: However, not everyone agrees that capital punishment is an effective deterrent or a just punishment. some argue that the jury giving the verdict are also humans. they have the life of a person at their discretion. they can make mistakes which can sometimes affect an innocent, circumstantially marred criminals. the jury must therefore, take into account the circumstances of committing a crime. for example, if an individual murders someone for self-defense, then such a crime is not heinous. only deserving criminals, who commit such hateful crimes in their proper senses are subjected to capital punishment.

Outcome.Outcome1: Students with best scholastic performance deserve university study because they have demonstrated their intellectual abilities and potentials in various subjects and fields. they have worked hard to achieve high grades and scores, which reflect their dedication, curiosity, and critical thinking. by entering university, they can further enhance their knowledge and skills, explore their interests and talents, and contribute to the advancement of science and society. they can also benefit from the diverse and stimulating academic environment, the rich and varied resources and opportunities, and the guidance and feedback from professors and peers.
Outcome.Outcome2: On the one hand, some might argue that university study is a privilege that should be reserved for students who excel academically. they may contend that university is an investment that requires high intellectual ability, motivation and dedication. moreover, they may point out that university education is costly and competitive, and that only the best performers can secure scholarships, grants and employment opportunities. therefore, they may suggest that university admission should be based on merit and academic achievement, and that students who do not meet the standards should seek other alternatives, such as vocational training or work experience.
Outcome.Outcome3: On the one hand, some may argue that university study is a privilege that should be reserved for the most outstanding students, who have demonstrated their academic excellence and potential. they may contend that university education is a scarce and costly resource that should be allocated based on merit and ability, not on personal preference or whim. they may also claim that admitting less qualified students would lower the academic standards and quality of university education, and undermine the value of the degrees and the reputation of the institutions. on the other hand, others may advocate for a more inclusive and diverse approach to university admission, as presented in the right text. they may point out that university is not just about academic studies but also a place to nurture artistic talent and develop soft skills. therefore, it should be up for grabs for a majority of young people, who wish to pursue their passion as well as develop comprehensively. they may argue that university education is a right and an opportunity that should be accessible and affordable for all, regardless of their academic performance or background. they may also suggest that admitting a wider range of students would enrich the university culture and environment, and foster creativity and innovation.
Outcome.Outcome4: While it is undeniable that scholastic excellence can give students an edge in university study and prepare them for the challenges of life, it is not the only criterion that matters. university is not just a place to acquire knowledge and skills, but also a place to explore one's interests and potentials, to express one's creativity and individuality, and to interact with people from diverse backgrounds and cultures. therefore, academic performance should not be the sole factor that determines who deserves university study.
Outcome.Outcome5: To some extent, it is understandable that students with outstanding academic achievements may have a stronger claim to university study, as they have demonstrated their intellectual abilities and diligence in their previous education. they may also have clear goals and ambitions that require higher education to fulfill. moreover, admitting the best students may enhance the reputation and quality of the university and benefit the society with their contributions.
Outcome.Outcome6: On the one hand, some may argue that university study is a privilege that should be reserved for the most academically capable students, who can demonstrate their excellence and potential in various fields of knowledge. they may contend that university education is a scarce and valuable resource that should be allocated based on merit and ability, rather than on personal preference or aspiration. they may also claim that university study requires a high level of intellectual rigor and discipline, which only the best scholastic performers can cope with and benefit from.

Outcome.Outcome4: However, limiting the violent and sexual content of the media is not the only reason why some people advocate for tighter media control. another issue is the influence of foreign programmes that television companies import from time to time, which may not suit the local culture and values. these programmes may expose the audiences to different norms and behaviours that are acceptable or even entertaining in other countries, but may be offensive or harmful in their own context. for example, a few years ago there was a japanese game show which involved throwing cream cakes to the loser. this is actually very environmentally unfriendly, as it wastes food and creates litter. moreover, it may also encourage disrespect and humiliation of others, which may contradict the local moral standards. therefore, some people may argue that television companies should be more selective and responsible in choosing the programmes they broadcast, and not just follow the market demand or the popularity of foreign media.
Outcome.Outcome5: While some people advocate for tighter media control, others oppose it on the grounds of freedom of expression and diversity of views. they argue that media consumers have the right to choose what they want to watch, read or listen to, and that they can critically evaluate the messages and values conveyed by different sources. moreover, they claim that restricting media content would stifle creativity, innovation and cultural exchange. for instance, they might point out that the internet cartoon comedy happy tree, despite its brutality, is a satire of violence and a form of artistic expression. similarly, they might defend the japanese game show as a harmless and humorous way of entertainment, and not as an example of environmental unfriendliness.
Outcome.Outcome6: However, opponents of media censorship argue that restricting the freedom of expression and information is a violation of human rights and democracy. they claim that viewers have the right to choose what they want to watch and that they can exercise their own judgment and critical thinking skills to evaluate the messages and values presented by the media. furthermore, they point out that banning or editing certain content does not necessarily prevent people from accessing it through other sources, such as the internet or illegal copies, and that it might even increase their curiosity and demand. therefore, they suggest that instead of imposing media control, the government and the society should provide more education and guidance to help people, especially young people, develop media literacy and moral awareness.

Context.Left: As illustrated before, several other solutions can be introduced to assist in reducing pollution and traffic problems. Primarily, authorities should spare no efforts in improving public transportation facilities, such as constructing more bus lines, in order to reducing the usage of private cars. Furthermore, temporarily targets should be set, with regard to the limitations of pollutants in a certain period of time, for example, a season. Plus with supervisory institutions built to find and address problems. Meanwhile, cultivating a sense of environmental protection would also work out, though it might not be into effect immediately, but in the long run, it would be a wise choice.

Prompt.Prompt1: Add a thesis statement that summarizes the main points of the essay and states your position on the topic of pollution and traffic problems.
Prompt.Prompt2: Provide some examples of how temporary targets and supervisory institutions can help monitor and control the levels of pollutants and enforce the relevant regulations.
Prompt.Prompt3: Add a connecting sentence that links the previous paragraph to the next one, using a contrast word such as however or nevertheless.
Prompt.Prompt4: Discuss the challenges and obstacles that might hinder the cultivation of a sense of environmental protection among the public and suggest some possible solutions or incentives.
Prompt.Prompt5: Write a paragraph to connect the left text and right text.
Prompt.Prompt6: Insert a passage connecting the two passages

Outcome.Outcome1: Pollution and traffic problems are two of the most serious challenges that many urban areas face today. they not only affect the health and well-being of the residents, but also damage the environment and the economy. therefore, it is essential to find effective and feasible solutions to tackle these issues and improve the quality of life in cities. in this essay, i will discuss some of the possible measures that can be taken by the authorities and the public to reduce pollution and traffic congestion, and explain why i support them. as illustrated before, several other solutions can be introduced to assist in reducing pollution and traffic problems. primarily, authorities should spare no efforts in improving public transportation facilities, such as constructing more bus lines, in order to reducing the usage of private cars. furthermore, temporarily targets should be set, with regard to the limitations of pollutants in a certain period of time, for example, a season. plus with supervisory institutions built to find and address problems. meanwhile, cultivating a sense of environmental protection would also work out, though it might not be into effect immediately, but in the long run, it would be a wise choice.
Outcome.Outcome2: One way to implement the temporary targets and supervisory institutions is to adopt a system of emission permits and trading, which can incentivize the polluters to reduce their emissions or pay for the excess. for instance, the european union has established a cap-and-trade scheme for greenhouse gases, which covers various sectors such as power generation, industry, and aviation. the scheme sets a limit on the total amount of emissions allowed in each period, and allocates permits to the participants, which they can trade in the market. the supervisory institutions are responsible for verifying the emissions and ensuring the compliance of the participants. another example is the congestion charge scheme in london, which aims to reduce traffic and air pollution in the city center. the scheme requires drivers to pay a daily fee to enter the designated zone during the peak hours, and uses cameras and license plate recognition to enforce the charge. the scheme is monitored and evaluated by the transport for london, which also invests the revenue from the charge in improving public transport and cycling infrastructure. these examples show how temporary targets and supervisory institutions can help monitor and control the levels of pollutants and enforce the relevant regulations.
Outcome.Outcome3: As illustrated before, several other solutions can be introduced to assist in reducing pollution and traffic problems. primarily, authorities should spare no efforts in improving public transportation facilities, such as constructing more bus lines, in order to reducing the usage of private cars. furthermore, temporarily targets should be set, with regard to the limitations of pollutants in a certain period of time, for example, a season. plus with supervisory institutions built to find and address problems. meanwhile, cultivating a sense of environmental protection would also work out, though it might not be into effect immediately, but in the long run, it would be a wise choice. however, these solutions are not without challenges and drawbacks, as the next paragraph will discuss.
Outcome.Outcome4: Providing more environmental education and information campaigns in schools, workplaces, and communities, to raise people's knowledge and understanding of the causes and effects of pollution and traffic problems, and the benefits of adopting more sustainable and eco-friendly lifestyles and practices.
Outcome.Outcome5: These solutions, however, may not be sufficient to tackle the root causes of pollution and traffic problems, which are often related to the urban planning and development patterns. therefore, in addition to the measures mentioned above, authorities should also consider adopting more holistic and long-term strategies to create a more sustainable and livable city. for instance, they could promote mixed-use development, which integrates residential, commercial, and recreational functions in a compact and walkable area, to reduce the need for long-distance commuting and car dependence. they could also enhance the green infrastructure, such as parks, gardens, and bike lanes, to provide more natural amenities and encourage low-carbon modes of transportation. moreover, they could involve the public and the stakeholders in the decision-making process, to ensure that the policies and plans reflect the needs and preferences of the community and foster a sense of ownership and responsibility.
Outcome.Outcome6: However, these solutions are not enough to tackle the root causes of pollution and traffic problems, which lie in the unsustainable patterns of production and consumption in modern society. therefore, more radical and long-term measures are also needed to address these issues.

Therefore, requiring students to study in many subjects is good for them.

This is because graduates can work in various kind of works which they can select a job they prefer. For example, students will choose a career that they want including the job with high salary include. Moreover, bachelors can earn lots of money by working in other fields due to their knowledge.

Prompt.Prompt1: Introduce the topic of the essay, which is the benefits of studying a variety of subjects in university, and provide a thesis statement that summarizes the main points.
Prompt.Prompt2: Provide some evidence or examples to support the claim that studying a variety of subjects can enhance students' skills and abilities.
Prompt.Prompt3: Add a connecting paragraph that makes the transition from the benefits of studying a variety of subjects to the benefits of having more career options smooth.

Outcome.Outcome1: Nowadays, many students face the challenge of choosing what subjects to study in university, as they have diverse interests and goals. however, studying a variety of subjects in university can have many benefits for students, both academically and personally. in this essay, i will argue that studying different subjects can help students to explore their potential, develop their skills, and increase their opportunities in the future.
Outcome.Outcome2: Studying a variety of subjects can also enhance students' skills and abilities in different aspects. for instance, students who learn science can develop their logical thinking and problem-solving skills, while students who learn music can improve their creativity and expression. similarly, students who take courses in humanities and social sciences can broaden their perspectives and cultural awareness, while students who take courses in languages and communication can enhance their verbal and written skills. by exposing themselves to diverse fields of knowledge, students can become more adaptable, flexible, and versatile in their learning and working environments.
Outcome.Outcome3: Studying a variety of subjects not only helps students to explore their interests and talents, but also prepares them for the challenges and opportunities of the modern world. in a rapidly changing and competitive society, employers value workers who have diverse skills, knowledge, and perspectives. therefore, having a broad education can give students an edge in the job market and enhance their employability.
Outcome.Outcome4: To sum up, studying a variety of subjects in university is beneficial for students in many ways. it helps them to explore their interests, broaden their perspectives, develop their skills, and enhance their creativity. it also prepares them for the challenges and opportunities of the modern world, where multidisciplinary knowledge and adaptability are essential. by studying a variety of subjects, students can not only enjoy their learning process, but also increase their chances of finding a satisfying and rewarding career. therefore, students should not limit themselves to one subject, but rather embrace the diversity and richness of learning in university.
Outcome.Outcome5: However, studying in many subjects is not only beneficial for students' personal interests and development, but also for their future prospects. in the competitive and changing job market, employers value candidates who have a broad range of skills and knowledge, as well as the ability to adapt and learn new things. therefore, students who expose themselves to different disciplines and perspectives during university can enhance their employability and flexibility.
Outcome.Outcome6: However, studying many subjects is not only beneficial for students' personal development and interest, but also for their future prospects and career choices. in a competitive and changing world, having a broad and diverse education can give graduates an edge over others who only focused on one field or discipline.

Outcome.Outcome1: However, not everyone agrees with the idea of zoos and their benefits. some people argue that zoos are unnatural and cruel for animals, who are deprived of their freedom, dignity and natural behaviors. they claim that zoos often confine animals in small and inadequate spaces, where they suffer from stress, boredom and loneliness. they also point out that zoos cannot replicate the complexity and diversity of the animals' wild habitats, and that many animals are exposed to diseases, injuries and abuse in captivity. moreover, they challenge the notion that zoos are educational or conservationist, as they believe that zoos distort the public's perception of animals and their needs, and that they do not address the root causes of the threats to wildlife, such as habitat loss, poaching and climate change. therefore, they suggest that zoos should be replaced by alternative ways of protecting and respecting animals, such as wildlife sanctuaries, reserves and rehabilitation centers.
Outcome.Outcome2: However, not everyone agrees with the idea of keeping animals in captivity for entertainment or conservation purposes. many critics of zoos argue that they violate the rights and welfare of animals, who are often subjected to stress, boredom, loneliness, and unnatural conditions. for example, some animals may suffer from a lack of space, social interaction, or environmental enrichment, which can lead to abnormal behaviors, health problems, or reduced lifespan. moreover, some zoos may not have adequate standards of care, hygiene, or veterinary services, exposing animals to diseases, injuries, or neglect. additionally, some ethical issues arise from the practice of breeding, trading, or euthanizing animals in zoos, which may interfere with their natural instincts, genetic diversity, or dignity. therefore, these critics suggest that zoos are more harmful than beneficial for animals and that alternative ways of conserving and educating about wildlife should be explored.
Outcome.Outcome3: However, not everyone agrees with the idea of confining animals in zoos. some critics argue that zoos are unethical and harmful to the welfare of the animals. they claim that zoos deprive animals of their natural behaviors, social interactions and habitats, and expose them to stress, boredom and diseases. they also challenge the educational and conservation value of zoos, as they believe that zoos do not teach people to respect animals or their environments, but rather to view them as objects of entertainment and exploitation. moreover, they contend that zoos are ineffective and costly in saving endangered species, and that more efforts should be directed to protecting their habitats and ecosystems in the wild. therefore, these critics oppose the existence of zoos and call for their abolition.
Outcome.Outcome4: Since the time they were introduced, zoos have both been supported and criticized. many believe that zoos could be very entertaining and ecologically important, whereas, others think that keeping animals in captivity is totally wrong. both sides will be discussed before a reasonable conclusion is drawn. however, not everyone agrees with the opponents of zoos and their ethical concerns. on the other hand, the advocators believe that zoos provide the public with good entertainment and also help to ensure the balance of the ecology. many people, especially young children enjoy going to zoos and see their favorite animals, cute baby-born animals and the animals that are from the different corners of the world. zoos provide educational information about the lives of different animals to the public. also, zoos play an important role in reserving many breeds of animal and preventing them from being missing from life. this is due to the fact that, in zoos, animals are kept in enclosures which simulate their own habitats and also endangered animals are being protected from their predators or hunters. thus zoos are needed to keep the nature balanced.
Outcome.Outcome5: However, there are also some strong arguments in favor of zoos and their benefits for both animals and humans. (this sentence introduces the opposite view and uses a contrast word to show the shift from the previous paragraph)
Outcome.Outcome6: However, not everyone agrees with the idea that zoos are beneficial for animals and humans. some critics argue that keeping animals in captivity is cruel and unnatural, and that zoos violate the rights and dignity of the animals. they claim that zoos deprive animals of their freedom, social interactions, and natural behaviors, and that zoos expose animals to stress, boredom, and diseases. moreover, they contend that zoos do not educate the public effectively, and that zoos do not contribute significantly to conservation efforts. they suggest that zoos are mainly driven by profit and entertainment, and that there are better alternatives to protect and study wildlife, such as sanctuaries, reserves, and field research. therefore, they oppose the existence of zoos and call for their closure.

Context.Right: However, the jury giving the verdict are also humans. They have the life of a person at their discretion. They can make mistakes which can sometimes affect an innocent, circumstantially marred criminals. The jury must therefore, take into account the circumstances of committing a crime. For example, if an individual murders someone for self-defense, then such a crime is not heinous. Outcome.Outcome1: Capital punishment, or the death penalty, is one of the most controversial and debated topics in the criminal justice system. some people argue that it is a necessary and effective deterrent for heinous crimes, while others contend that it is a violation of human rights and prone to errors. in this essay, i will examine the arguments for and against capital punishment, and explore the ethical and practical implications of this practice.
Outcome.Outcome2: Capital punishment is a controversial issue that has supporters and opponents on both sides. those who favor it argue that it is a deterrent for hateful crimes, such as murder, rape, or terrorism, that violate the basic rights and dignity of human beings. they claim that capital punishment curbs the inspiration and prospects of other hateful crimes, as it instills fear and respect for the law in potential offenders. they cite studies that show a correlation between the presence of the death penalty and the reduction of homicide rates in some countries or states. moreover, they assert that capital punishment serves the purpose of justice and retribution, as it gives closure and satisfaction to the victims and their families.
Outcome.Outcome3: Moreover, capital punishment curbs the inspiration and prospects of other hateful crimes. when a criminal mind knows the quantum of punishment, they will fear and not commit such crimes. thus, the rate of crime and violence is effectively decreased. however, the jury giving the verdict are also humans. they have the life of a person at their discretion. they can make mistakes which can sometimes affect an innocent, circumstantially marred criminals. the jury must therefore, take into account the circumstances of committing a crime. for example, if an individual murders someone for self-defense, then such a crime is not heinous. in such a case, the person acted out of necessity and fear for their own life, and did not intend to kill. this is different from a premeditated murder, where the person planned and executed the killing with malice and motive. only deserving criminals, who commit such hateful crimes in their proper senses are subjected to capital punishment.
Outcome.Outcome4: In conclusion, capital punishment is a controversial topic that has both supporters and opponents. some argue that it is a just and deterrent measure that prevents further crimes and expresses the society's condemnation of heinous acts. others contend that it is a flawed and inhumane practice that can result in wrongful convictions and disregard the circumstances of the offenders. the jury should carefully examine the evidence and the motives of the criminals before deciding their fate. capital punishment should only be applied to the most deserving and culpable cases, where there is no doubt of guilt and no possibility of reform.
Outcome.Outcome5: Capital punishment can deter potential offenders from committing heinous crimes by instilling fear of the ultimate penalty. however, not all crimes are equally deserving of such a harsh punishment. the jury should consider the context and motive of the crime, and differentiate between intentional and accidental or defensive acts of violence. otherwise, they might end up sentencing an innocent or unjustly accused person to death, which would be a grave injustice and a violation of human rights.
Outcome.Outcome6: While capital punishment may have a deterrent effect on some potential offenders, it also raises serious ethical and legal issues for the justice system. not only does it involve taking away a person's life, but it also relies on the accuracy and fairness of the jury's decision.

Outcome.Outcome1: Communication is an essential skill in any workplace, as it facilitates collaboration, problem-solving, and innovation. however, some people may prefer to work from home rather than in the office, citing reasons such as flexibility, comfort, and productivity. in this essay, i will argue that working in the office has more advantages than working from home in terms of communication. first of all, while working in the office, people can interact with their colleges instantly. they can either get help from colleges or discuss about the work together. think about the big project that a group is working on, if any group member has new idea about the project, he/she can assemble his/her colleges right away and discuss. it's more efficient and straight-forward than talking in the phone. for another example, if ones computer or internet has any breakdown, he/she can call the mis staff to fix.
Outcome.Outcome2: Face-to-face communication is not only more convenient, but also more effective than phone communication in the office. according to a study by harvard business review, face-to-face meetings are 34% more likely to produce positive outcomes than virtual ones. moreover, face-to-face communication can enhance trust, rapport, and nonverbal cues among co-workers, which are essential for collaboration and innovation. first of all, while working in the office, people can interact with their colleges instantly. they can either get help from colleges or discuss about the work together. think about the big project that a group is working on, if any group member has new idea about the project, he/she can assemble his/her colleges right away and discuss. it's more efficient and straight-forward than talking in the phone. for another example, if ones computer or internet has any breakdown, he/she can call the mis staff to fix.
Outcome.Outcome3: One of the benefits of working in the office is that people can interact with their colleagues instantly, which can foster teamwork and collaboration. face-to-face communication allows people to exchange information, feedback, and opinions more effectively and clearly than phone or online communication. it also helps to build trust, rapport, and mutual understanding among team members, which are essential for successful cooperation. for instance, when working on a big project, people can easily share their ideas, brainstorm solutions, and coordinate tasks by meeting in person. they can also seek help or advice from their colleagues when they encounter any difficulties or challenges. moreover, face-to-face communication can also enhance the morale and motivation of the team, as people can express their appreciation, recognition, and support to each other. therefore, working in the office can facilitate the development of a cohesive and productive team.
Outcome.Outcome4: However, relying on phone communication in the workplace may pose some challenges or disadvantages for the employees and the organization. for instance, phone communication can cause miscommunication if the speaker or the listener is not clear, concise, or attentive. the tone, gesture, and facial expression that are important for conveying meaning and emotion are lost in phone communication, which can lead to misunderstanding, confusion, or conflict. moreover, phone communication can be distracting and disruptive for the work environment, especially if there are multiple calls, noises, or interruptions. the employees may lose focus, concentration, or motivation if they have to constantly switch between tasks or deal with irrelevant or urgent calls. furthermore, phone communication can limit the feedback and evaluation that are essential for improving the work quality and performance. the employees may not receive immediate, constructive, or specific feedback from their colleagues, managers, or clients, which can affect their learning, growth, and satisfaction. therefore, phone communication may not be the best option for some work situations that require face-to-face interaction, collaboration, or problem-solving.
Outcome.Outcome5: Communicating with co-workers is one of the main advantages of working in the office rather than at home. first of all, while working in the office, people can interact with their colleges instantly. they can either get help from colleges or discuss about the work together. think about the big project that a group is working on, if any group member has new idea about the project, he/she can assemble his/her colleges right away and discuss. it's more efficient and straight-forward than talking in the phone. for another example, if ones computer or internet has any breakdown, he/she can call the mis staff to fix. in contrast, working at home may pose some challenges for effective collaboration and problem-solving.
Outcome.Outcome6: However, working in the office also has some drawbacks that can affect people's productivity and well-being. one of the main disadvantages is the lack of flexibility and autonomy in choosing when and where to work. people who work in the office have to follow a fixed schedule and commute to the same location every day, regardless of their personal preferences, circumstances, or mood. this can cause stress, boredom, and dissatisfaction, especially for those who have to deal with traffic, noise, or other environmental factors that can interfere with their concentration and creativity. moreover, working in the office can also limit people's opportunities to balance their work and life, as they may have less time and energy to pursue their hobbies, interests, or family responsibilities.

Context.Left: Nevertheless, opponents of online-degrees would argue that attending lectures in person provides students an opportunity to communicate with teachers and other classmates. They further point out that traditional teaching approaches involving discussion and cooperation among students play a significant role in campus life. It is the real interactions and communications in class make education much more attractive.

Prompt.Prompt1: Introduce the topic of online-degrees and the main arguments for and against them in the first paragraph.
Prompt.Prompt2: Explain how online-degrees offer flexibility and convenience for students who have other commitments or live far from campus in the second paragraph.
Prompt.Prompt3: Acknowledge the counterargument that online-degrees lack the social and interactive aspects of traditional education in the third paragraph.
Prompt.Prompt4: Rebut the counterargument by showing how online-degrees can also foster communication and collaboration among students and teachers through various technologies and platforms in the fourth paragraph.
Prompt.Prompt5: Write a paragraph to connect the left text and right text.
Prompt.Prompt6: Insert a passage connecting the two passages

Outcome.Outcome1: Online-degrees have become increasingly popular in recent years, especially in the context of the covid-19 pandemic that has disrupted many educational institutions. online-degrees offer students the flexibility and convenience of learning from anywhere and at any time, as well as the potential to reduce the costs and barriers of accessing higher education. however, not everyone is convinced that online-degrees can provide the same quality and value as traditional degrees. some of the main arguments for and against online-degrees are as follows.
Outcome.Outcome2: However, these arguments do not take into account the benefits of online-degrees for many students who face various challenges in attending lectures in person. online-degrees offer flexibility and convenience for students who have other commitments, such as work, family, or health issues, or live far from campus. they can access the course materials and assignments at any time and pace that suits their needs and preferences. they can also interact with teachers and classmates through online platforms, such as forums, chats, or video calls, and participate in collaborative learning activities. online-degrees can also expose students to diverse perspectives and cultures from different regions and countries.
Outcome.Outcome3: However, supporters of online-degrees could counter that the lack of face-to-face interaction does not necessarily imply a lower quality of education or a diminished sense of community. they could point to the various technological tools and platforms that enable online students to communicate and collaborate with their instructors and peers, such as video conferencing, online forums, chat rooms, and social media. they could also argue that online-degrees offer more flexibility and convenience for students who have other commitments or preferences, such as work, family, or travel. moreover, they could claim that online-degrees expose students to a more diverse and global perspective, as they can interact with people from different backgrounds and cultures.
Outcome.Outcome4: However, this counterargument overlooks the fact that online-degrees can also foster communication and collaboration among students and teachers through various technologies and platforms. for instance, online students can use video conferencing, chat rooms, forums, and social media to interact with their instructors and peers in real time or asynchronously. they can also participate in group projects, case studies, simulations, and online communities of practice that enhance their learning and engagement. moreover, online-degrees can offer students access to a wider and more diverse network of experts, mentors, and fellow learners from different backgrounds, disciplines, and locations. therefore, online-degrees do not necessarily compromise the quality and richness of the educational experience.
Outcome.Outcome5: However, the benefits of online-degrees are not without drawbacks. nevertheless, opponents of online-degrees would argue that attending lectures in person provides students an opportunity to communicate with teachers and other classmates. they further point out that traditional teaching approaches involving discussion and cooperation among students play a significant role in campus life. it is the real interactions and communications in class that make education much more attractive. in contrast, online-degrees may limit the chances of developing social and interpersonal skills, as well as creating a sense of belonging and community among learners. moreover, some online courses may lack the quality and rigor of face-to-face instruction, and may not be recognized or accredited by some employers or institutions.
Outcome.Outcome6: However, these arguments do not take into account the advantages of online-degrees for students who face various challenges or limitations in accessing traditional education. for instance, online-degrees can offer more flexibility and convenience for students who have work or family commitments, who live in remote or rural areas, or who have physical or mental disabilities. moreover, online-degrees can also foster communication and collaboration among students and teachers through various digital tools and platforms, such as video conferencing, online forums, and social media. therefore, online-degrees do not necessarily imply a loss of quality or engagement in education, but rather a different and innovative way of learning.

Context.Left: Most importantly, people prone to work in two or three firms in a week because the expenses have been increased. If they work just in one organization they cannot earn enough money. This fact pushes them to work faster and faster. For example, because applying to study abroad needs a lot of money, I am working in two organization to gain more salary. The more money, the more chances.
Context.Right: To sum up, I completely approve of the statement which says people should work faster even more risky. Gaining more skills by study, having more than one job, and handling more tasks are the benefits of it which overweighs its disadvantages. I hope people gain this skill because after that they will endorse my choice.

Prompt.Prompt1: Introduce the topic of working faster and more riskily in the current society and state your opinion in the first paragraph.
Prompt.Prompt2: Explain the first reason why you agree with the statement that people should work faster and more riskily, which is gaining more skills by studying.
Prompt.Prompt3: Elaborate on the second reason why you agree with the statement that people should work faster and more riskily, which is having more than one job.
