Outcome.Outcome1: One of the main arguments against the idea of relying on tv as a learning tool is that it deprives children of the benefits of traditional education. traditional education, which involves attending classes, doing homework, reading books, and interacting with teachers and peers, has been proven to be effective in developing various cognitive, social, and emotional skills. moreover, traditional education exposes children to a wide range of subjects, perspectives, and experiences that can enrich their knowledge and curiosity. therefore, it is preferable to have students spend more time on traditional education than on tv.
Outcome.Outcome2: One of the benefits of traditional education is that it fosters critical thinking and problem-solving skills in children. unlike watching tv, which often provides ready-made information and opinions, traditional education requires students to engage with various sources of knowledge, analyze arguments, and construct their own responses. for example, in a classroom setting, students can discuss different perspectives on a topic, debate with their peers, and write essays that demonstrate their understanding and reasoning. these skills are essential for developing a sense of curiosity, independence, and responsibility, as well as for preparing them for the challenges and opportunities of the 21st century.
Outcome.Outcome3: Traditional education methods, such as reading, writing, speaking, listening, and problem-solving, can cater to different types of learners and foster their cognitive, linguistic, and social development. for example, reading books can enhance vocabulary, comprehension, and imagination; writing essays can improve communication, organization, and critical thinking; speaking and listening can promote oral expression, interaction, and feedback; and problem-solving can stimulate creativity, logic, and collaboration. these methods can also expose children to diverse topics, perspectives, and cultures, enriching their knowledge and curiosity. therefore, traditional education has its stand for most appropriate method.
Outcome.Outcome4: One of the drawbacks of watching tv for learning is that it can affect children's attention span and memory. tv programs often have fast-paced, flashy, and distracting elements that can reduce the ability of children to focus and retain information. moreover, watching tv does not require active engagement or interaction, which are essential for deep and meaningful learning. children who watch tv for long hours may also miss out on opportunities to practice and apply their knowledge in different contexts and situations. therefore, watching tv is not a suitable substitute for traditional education, which has its stand for most appropriate method.
Outcome.Outcome5: One of the main drawbacks of learning by watching tv is that it deprives children of the opportunity to engage in more active and interactive forms of education. traditional education, despite its possible flaws, offers a variety of ways to stimulate children's curiosity, creativity, and critical thinking through classroom discussions, experiments, projects, and field trips. these methods not only enhance children's knowledge, but also develop their social and emotional skills, such as communication, collaboration, and problem-solving. therefore, spending more time on tvs may limit children's exposure to such beneficial educational experiences.
Outcome.Outcome6: One of the main drawbacks of relying on television as a learning tool is that it deprives children of the benefits of traditional education, which involves interaction with teachers and peers, exposure to diverse subjects and perspectives, and development of critical thinking and problem-solving skills. traditional education has its stand for the most appropriate method because it fosters a holistic and balanced growth of an individual, not only in terms of knowledge, but also in terms of social, emotional, and physical well-being. therefore, physical inactivity should not be discouraged for the aim of bettering youngsters' skills. secondly, watching television is a very passive action and should not be promoted by increasing periods spent on it.

Context.Left: To begin with, it is the right of wild species to live in a environment away from human beings. Given the fact that human beings are responsible for the heavy pollution and severe damage to the natural habitats of many wild animals, it is our responsibility to create a natural and safe environment for animals to live in. Apparently, the limited space and the artificial trees and lakes can not fully compensate the animals for their loss. Moreover, if rural animals are captured in the zoo for a long period, it would have negative influences on both the physical and psychological status of the creatures. As a result, the wild species would suffer from isolation and depression. It seems that zoos are more likely to be a killer rather than a protector in protecting wild lives.
Context.Right: By way of conclusion, it is my belief that wild animals should be set free from zoos not only because they have the right to enjoy freedom but they also escape from isolation and depression.

Prompt.Prompt1: Introduce the topic of whether wild animals should be kept in zoos or not and state your position clearly.
Prompt.Prompt2: Provide some supporting arguments for your position and use relevant examples or evidence to back them up.
Prompt.Prompt3: Acknowledge the possible counterarguments or objections to your position and explain why they are not convincing or valid.
Prompt.Prompt4: End with a strong statement or a question that leaves a lasting impression on the reader and reinforces your stance.
Prompt.Prompt5: Write a paragraph to connect the left text and right text.
Prompt.Prompt6: Insert a passage connecting the two passages

Outcome.Outcome1: Zoos are often regarded as places where people can appreciate the diversity and beauty of wild animals, as well as learn more about their behaviors and characteristics. however, some people argue that keeping wild animals in zoos is unethical and harmful to their well-being. in this essay, i will support the latter view and explain why wild animals should be set free from zoos. there are two main reasons for my stance: the right of wild animals to live in a natural environment and the negative impact of captivity on their health and happiness.
Outcome.Outcome2: Some people may argue that zoos have educational and conservation benefits for both humans and animals. however, i disagree with this view for several reasons. first, zoos can not provide adequate and authentic information about the natural behaviors and characteristics of wild animals, as they are often confined in unnatural and stressful conditions. therefore, zoos may mislead the public and create a false impression of wildlife. second, zoos can not effectively conserve endangered species, as they often breed animals for commercial and entertainment purposes, rather than for restoring their populations in the wild. furthermore, zoos may interfere with the genetic diversity and adaptation of animals, as they are exposed to artificial selection and inbreeding. third, zoos can not justify the ethical and moral issues of depriving animals of their freedom and dignity, as they are subjected to human domination and exploitation. hence, zoos may violate the intrinsic value and rights of animals as sentient beings.
Outcome.Outcome3: However, some people may argue that zoos are beneficial for wild animals in several ways. for instance, they may claim that zoos provide animals with food, medical care, and protection from predators and poachers. they may also contend that zoos have educational and scientific value, as they allow people to learn more about animal behavior and conservation, and conduct research on endangered species. yet, these arguments are not convincing or valid for several reasons. first, zoos often fail to meet the basic needs and preferences of animals, such as adequate space, social interaction, and environmental enrichment. second, zoos may cause more harm than good to animal welfare, as they expose animals to stress, boredom, and disease. third, zoos may undermine the conservation efforts, as they reduce the genetic diversity and the survival skills of animals, and divert resources and attention from the protection of natural habitats. therefore, zoos are not the best solution for preserving and respecting wild animals.
Outcome.Outcome4: Therefore, keeping wild animals in zoos is not only unethical but also harmful for their well-being. zoos deprive animals of their natural instincts, social bonds, and environmental diversity, and expose them to stress, boredom, and diseases. instead of confining animals in cages and enclosures, we should respect their dignity and autonomy, and support conservation efforts that protect their habitats and populations in the wild. how can we claim to love and care for animals when we rob them of their essence and identity?
Outcome.Outcome5: Therefore, keeping wild animals in zoos is not a humane or effective way of preserving biodiversity and wildlife conservation. zoos deprive animals of their natural rights and cause them physical and psychological harm. instead of confining animals in cages and enclosures, we should respect their autonomy and dignity and protect their habitats from human interference and destruction.
Outcome.Outcome6: Therefore, keeping wild animals in zoos is not a humane or effective way of conserving them. on the contrary, it deprives them of their natural instincts, behaviors, and social interactions, which are essential for their well-being and survival. zoos also fail to educate the public about the real needs and challenges of wild animals, and instead present a distorted and simplified image of their lives. rather than supporting zoos, we should support efforts to protect and restore the natural habitats of wild animals, and to reduce the human impacts that threaten their existence.

Context.Left: In terms of ethics, it is inhumane to watch one's fellowman struggle against famine and poverty without doing anything to help, especially when the onlooker takes no effort to do so. Compassion, a virtue preached in almost all religions from Buddhism to Mohammedanism, is what distinguishes us human beings from animals.
Context.Right: In summary, wealthy nations' offering in need is not only a moral deed, but also a worthwhile one which will one day pay off in other ways. Only those who sympathize with their fellowman can prosper in the long run.

Prompt.Prompt1: Provide some examples of how compassion can benefit both the giver and the receiver.
Prompt.Prompt2: Add a connecting paragraph that makes the transition from compassion to other benefits of helping smooth.
Prompt.Prompt3: Discuss some of the other benefits of helping, such as improving global security, health, and trade.
Prompt.Prompt4: Summarize the main points of your argument and restate your thesis in a different way.
Prompt.Prompt5: Write a paragraph to connect the left text and right text.
Prompt.Prompt6: Insert a passage connecting the two passages

Outcome.Outcome1: Compassion can benefit both the giver and the receiver in various ways. for the giver, compassion can enhance one's sense of well-being, happiness, and gratitude, as well as foster positive relationships and social bonds. for the receiver, compassion can alleviate suffering, provide hope and dignity, and empower them to overcome challenges and pursue their goals. moreover, compassion can create a ripple effect of kindness and generosity, as the receiver may in turn help others in need, or express gratitude and appreciation to the giver. thus, compassion can enrich the lives of both parties and contribute to a more harmonious and humane society.
Outcome.Outcome2: However, compassion is not the only motive that should drive wealthy nations to assist those who suffer from hunger and deprivation. there are also practical and strategic reasons why such generosity is beneficial for both the giver and the receiver. by sharing their resources and expertise, rich countries can foster goodwill, stability, and cooperation among the less fortunate regions of the world. they can also prevent or mitigate the negative impacts of global problems such as conflicts, epidemics, and environmental degradation, which affect everyone regardless of their location or income. furthermore, they can create new opportunities for trade, investment, and innovation by tapping into the potential and diversity of the developing world.
Outcome.Outcome3: Helping the poor and hungry is not only a matter of ethics, but also of prudence and foresight. by sharing their resources and expertise, wealthy nations can improve the living conditions and prospects of millions of people who otherwise would face despair and violence. this, in turn, can enhance the global security, health, and trade, as poverty and famine are often the root causes of conflicts, diseases, and instability. by fostering compassion and cooperation, wealthy nations can also build trust and goodwill with other countries and cultures, which can facilitate diplomatic and economic relations. thus, helping the needy is not only a moral deed, but also a worthwhile one which will one day pay off in other ways.
Outcome.Outcome4: To watch the suffering of others and do nothing is not only unethical, but also foolish. by sharing their resources and expertise, rich countries can foster goodwill, cooperation, and peace among the nations of the world. they can also benefit from the development and innovation that can arise from alleviating poverty and hunger. compassion is not only a noble virtue, but also a wise strategy for human progress. therefore, i argue that wealthy nations have a moral and practical obligation to help the poor and the hungry.
Outcome.Outcome5: Therefore, it is the duty of the affluent countries to share their resources and expertise with the less fortunate ones, who are suffering from hunger and deprivation. by doing so, they are not only fulfilling their ethical obligations, but also investing in a more peaceful and stable world. in summary, wealthy nations' offering in need is not only a moral deed, but also a worthwhile one which will one day pay off in other ways.
Outcome.Outcome6: Therefore, it is the duty of the rich countries to share their resources and expertise with the poor ones, not only to alleviate their suffering, but also to foster a sense of global solidarity and cooperation. by helping the less fortunate, they are not only fulfilling their ethical obligations, but also investing in their own future security and prosperity. as the world becomes more interconnected and interdependent, the problems of one region can affect the others, and the solutions of one region can benefit the others.

Prompt.Prompt2: Provide some statistics or evidence to support the claim that using technology or advanced facilities can save time and ensure nutrition and quality of food.
Prompt.Prompt3: Compare and contrast the advantages and disadvantages of cooking food by oneself and using technology or advanced facilities, and give some examples or scenarios to illustrate the points.
Prompt.Prompt4: Summarize the main arguments and restate the thesis statement, and give some suggestions or recommendations for the readers on how to balance time management and food quality.
Prompt.Prompt5: Write a paragraph to connect the left text and right text.
Prompt.Prompt6: Insert a passage connecting the two passages

Outcome.Outcome1: In the modern society, time is a valuable resource that people need to manage wisely and efficiently. one of the activities that can consume a lot of time is cooking food, especially for those who have busy schedules and multiple responsibilities. however, cooking food does not necessarily mean spending hours in the kitchen and compromising nutrition and quality of food. some people may argue that investing much time in cooking food will guarantee nutrition as well as quality of food for their family. to some extent, it is true. however, as a matter of fact, using technology or advanced facilities do not make food lose its nutrition and quality. even, with the help of ozone machines, bacterias, mold spores, or pesticide in vegetables, fruits and foods will be killed and removed, thus health and life of eaters is assured. besides, along with the high living standard, requirements of quality products in almost restaurants, nowadays, are under severe control and supervision by appropriate authorities. consequently, it is quite easy to have a nutritious meal with guaranteed quality, but do not waste a lot of time. therefore, by utilizing technology or advanced facilities to prepare food, people can save time, energy, and money, while still enjoying delicious and healthy food.
Outcome.Outcome2: The benefits of using technology or advanced facilities to prepare food are not only theoretical, but also supported by empirical data. according to a study by the food and agriculture organization, using ozone machines can reduce the microbial load and pesticide residues of fresh produce by up to 90%, while preserving the sensory and nutritional qualities (fao, 2016). another study by the university of illinois found that microwave cooking can retain more vitamin c, folate, and antioxidants in broccoli than boiling or steaming (zhang and hamouz, 2012). moreover, a survey by the national restaurant association revealed that 78% of consumers say that food safety and quality are the most important factors when choosing a restaurant, and 68% of restaurants use technology to monitor and improve their food safety practices (nra, 2019). therefore, using technology or advanced facilities can save time and ensure nutrition and quality of food, without compromising the taste and satisfaction of the consumers.
Outcome.Outcome3: Cooking food by oneself and using technology or advanced facilities are two different ways of preparing meals for one's family. each way has its own advantages and disadvantages, depending on the preferences, resources, and circumstances of the cook. cooking food by oneself can ensure nutrition and quality of food, as well as provide a sense of satisfaction and creativity. however, it can also be time-consuming, exhausting, and costly, especially for busy people who have to balance work, family, and other responsibilities. using technology or advanced facilities, on the other hand, can save time, energy, and money, as well as offer convenience and variety. for example, using an ozone machine can eliminate harmful substances from food, and ordering food from a restaurant can cater to different tastes and dietary needs. however, using technology or advanced facilities can also pose some risks, such as losing control over the ingredients, quality, and freshness of food, or relying too much on external sources and losing the skills and traditions of cooking. therefore, the best way of preparing meals for one's family may depend on the situation and the goals of the cook.
Outcome.Outcome4: In conclusion, the idea that spending more time on cooking food is the only way to ensure nutrition and quality for one's family is not convincing. technology and advanced facilities can help preserve and enhance the food's value, while eating out can also be a safe and satisfying option, as long as the restaurants follow the quality standards. therefore, the readers should not feel guilty or stressed about not having enough time to cook food, but rather look for ways to optimize their time management and food choices. some suggestions are to plan ahead the weekly menu, use online delivery services or smart appliances, or explore different cuisines and dishes that are both healthy and delicious. by doing so, the readers can enjoy the benefits of food without sacrificing their other priorities and interests.
Outcome.Outcome5: Therefore, the claim that spending much time in cooking food is the only way to ensure nutrition and quality of food for one's family is not convincing. technology and advanced facilities can also help to preserve and enhance the food's benefits, as well as to eliminate harmful substances. moreover, eating out at restaurants is not necessarily a bad choice, as long as they follow the standards and regulations of food safety and hygiene. hence, people can save time and enjoy a variety of dishes without compromising their health and well-being.
Outcome.Outcome6: Therefore, the claim that spending much time in cooking food is necessary for nutrition and quality is not convincing. there are other ways to ensure that the food we consume is healthy and safe, without sacrificing our precious time and energy. in fact, using technology or advanced facilities can enhance the benefits of food and make it more convenient and accessible.

Context.Right: No one can argue the importance to include health lessons in school programmes, especially at primary level, in the hope of raising people's awareness. Children should be taught about balanced diets, nutritious food as well as harmful ones, thereby they will have a fundamental grasp of how to lead a healthy lifestyle. What is more, it is much easier for people at early ages to form a habit of, for instance, not consuming too much fast food, over-fried food or intoxicants.

Prompt.Prompt1: Introduce the topic of health lessons in school programmes and state your main argument in the first paragraph.
Prompt.Prompt2: Provide some evidence or examples to support your argument in the second paragraph.
Prompt.Prompt3: Add a connecting sentence at the end of the second paragraph that links to the next point of discussion.
Prompt.Prompt4: Discuss the benefits of health lessons for children's physical and mental well-being in the third paragraph.
Prompt.Prompt5: Write a paragraph to connect the left text and right text.
Prompt.Prompt6: Insert a passage connecting the two passages

Outcome.Outcome1: Health is one of the most valuable assets that people can have, and it is influenced by various factors, such as diet, exercise, environment and personal choices. therefore, it is essential that people learn how to take care of their health from an early age, and that education plays a key role in this process. in this essay, i will argue that health lessons should be included in school programmes, especially at primary level, in order to raise people's awareness and foster healthy habits. no one can argue the importance to include health lessons in school programmes, especially at primary level, in the hope of raising people's awareness. children should be taught about balanced diets, nutritious food as well as harmful ones, thereby they will have a fundamental grasp of how to lead a healthy lifestyle. what is more, it is much easier for people at early ages to form a habit of, for instance, not consuming too much fast food, over-fried food or intoxicants.
Outcome.Outcome2: Some evidence or examples to support the argument that health lessons are important in school programmes can be drawn from various sources. for instance, a study by the world health organization (who) found that health education in schools can improve students' knowledge, attitudes and skills related to nutrition, physical activity, hygiene and mental health, and reduce the risk of obesity, diabetes, cardiovascular diseases and other chronic conditions (who, 2018). another example is the health promoting schools (hps) initiative, which is a holistic approach that integrates health education with school policies, environment, partnerships and services to create a healthy and supportive learning community (lee et al., 2016). hps has been implemented in many countries and regions, such as australia, canada, china, europe and the pacific, and has shown positive outcomes in terms of students' health, academic performance, social and emotional well-being and civic engagement (lee et al., 2016).
Outcome.Outcome3: No one can argue the importance to include health lessons in school programmes, especially at primary level, in the hope of raising people's awareness. children should be taught about balanced diets, nutritious food as well as harmful ones, thereby they will have a fundamental grasp of how to lead a healthy lifestyle. what is more, it is much easier for people at early ages to form a habit of, for instance, not consuming too much fast food, over-fried food or intoxicants. however, health education alone is not enough to prevent or reduce the risks of various diseases and disorders that may affect children and adults alike. therefore, another essential aspect of promoting health and well-being is physical activity.
Outcome.Outcome4: Besides providing children with basic knowledge of health and nutrition, health lessons can also have positive effects on their physical and mental well-being. by learning about the benefits of regular exercise, proper hygiene, and stress management, children can develop healthy habits that can prevent various diseases and disorders in the future. moreover, health lessons can also foster children's self-esteem, confidence, and social skills, as they can learn to appreciate their own bodies, respect others' choices, and cooperate with their peers in group activities. therefore, health lessons can help children to grow up as well-rounded and responsible individuals.
Outcome.Outcome5: One way to implement health lessons in school programmes is to incorporate physical activities and exercises into the curriculum. by doing so, children can not only learn about the benefits of staying fit and active, but also practice them on a regular basis. physical activities and exercises can help children improve their cardiovascular health, strengthen their muscles and bones, enhance their coordination and balance, and reduce their stress and anxiety levels. moreover, they can also foster children's social skills, teamwork, and self-confidence, as they interact with their peers and teachers in various sports and games. therefore, physical activities and exercises are essential components of health education that can complement the knowledge and skills that children acquire from learning about balanced diets and nutritious food.
Outcome.Outcome6: Besides educating children about food choices, health lessons in school programmes should also cover other aspects of physical and mental well-being. for example, they should learn about the benefits of regular exercise, proper hygiene, stress management and positive relationships. these topics can help children develop skills and attitudes that will enable them to cope with various challenges and opportunities in life. moreover, by fostering a culture of health and wellness in schools, teachers and parents can also set good examples and reinforce the messages conveyed in the curriculum.

Context.Left: To start with, the fairness between males and females is inevitable in such a developed society. Gone are the days when women could do nothing rather than stick to boring house work and take care of children. Women nowadays are much more active, they may be successful businessmen, they join the political world, they become scientists and so on. This is to say, the "weaker" gender as often be thought has enough right as well as ability to contribute to the development of human beings just like any other men, not to mention they even perform better in some fields.
Context.Right: Admittedly, such changes do lead to some negative results like an upward trend in divorce rate or, under many circumstances, women find it difficult to balance their work and their traditional role as the wives. Also, children might enjoy less care from parents as they are both busy with their work. Yet everything has it upside and downside, women should find the best way to overcome such challenges.

Prompt.Prompt1: Explain why fairness between males and females is inevitable in such a developed society.
Prompt.Prompt2: Provide some examples of how women have contributed to the development of human beings in different fields.
Prompt.Prompt3: State the main argument of the right text and support it with evidence or reasoning.
Prompt.Prompt4: Conclude the essay by summarizing the main points and suggesting some possible solutions or implications.
Prompt.Prompt5: Write a paragraph to connect the left text and right text.
Prompt.Prompt6: Insert a passage connecting the two passages

Outcome.Outcome1: Fairness between males and females is inevitable in such a developed society because it is not only a matter of human rights, but also a source of social progress and economic growth. women, who make up half of the population, have the potential and the aspiration to participate in various fields of endeavor and to demonstrate their talents and creativity. by empowering women and ensuring their equal opportunities and treatment, society can benefit from their diverse perspectives, skills and contributions. moreover, fairness between males and females can also foster a culture of respect, cooperation and mutual understanding, which can enhance the quality of life and the harmony of the society.
Outcome.Outcome2: Women have contributed to the development of human beings in different fields in various ways. for example, women have made remarkable achievements in literature, arts, education, medicine, law, and human rights. some notable women who have left their mark on history include jane austen, frida kahlo, marie curie, rosa parks, malala yousafzai, and ruth bader ginsburg. these women and many others have demonstrated their creativity, intelligence, courage, and leadership in the face of challenges and discrimination. they have also inspired and empowered other women and girls to pursue their dreams and aspirations.
Outcome.Outcome3: However, the increasing equality between men and women does not mean that they have to abandon their distinctive roles and responsibilities in the family and society. on the contrary, it means that they have to cooperate and complement each other in order to achieve a harmonious and prosperous life. for example, studies have shown that couples who share household chores and child care are more satisfied and less stressed than those who adhere to traditional gender norms. moreover, children who grow up in families where both parents are involved and supportive tend to have better academic, social and emotional outcomes than those who lack parental guidance or attention. therefore, it is not the equality itself that causes problems, but the lack of communication, understanding and flexibility among family members.
Outcome.Outcome4: To conclude, the essay has discussed the fairness between males and females in the modern society and how it affects various aspects of life. it has argued that women have the right and the ability to participate in different fields and achieve their goals, while acknowledging some of the challenges and drawbacks that come with this change. to cope with these issues, women need to find effective ways to balance their work and family responsibilities, and to seek support from their partners, employers, and society. moreover, men and women should respect each other's choices and roles, and work together to create a more harmonious and equitable society.
Outcome.Outcome5: However, the pursuit of fairness between males and females does not mean that they can ignore the differences and responsibilities that exist between them. in fact, achieving gender equality requires not only the empowerment of women, but also the respect and cooperation of men. both genders need to recognize and appreciate each other's roles and contributions in various aspects of life, and support each other in fulfilling their potential and overcoming their challenges. only by doing so can they create a harmonious and sustainable society that benefits everyone.
Outcome.Outcome6: However, the fairness between males and females does not mean that they have to be identical in every aspect of life. there are still some natural differences and social expectations that affect their choices and responsibilities. for instance, women are more likely to bear the burden of childbearing and rearing, which may limit their career opportunities or require them to sacrifice some personal interests. men, on the other hand, may face more pressure to be the breadwinners and providers of the family, which may reduce their involvement in domestic affairs or emotional support. therefore, achieving a harmonious and respectful relationship between the two genders requires not only legal and institutional measures, but also mutual understanding and compromise.

Context.Right: In a positive point of view, when people without jobs have hand phones that have access to the Internet, they will be able to browse the net for more job opportunities. For example, they can surf the The Star Onlines' work section to find a job that is suitable for them. With the help of the net, they can also do more research on the work that they have found apart from looking up on how they can prepare themselves for the job. Not only that, the mobile phones can also be used to make calls with the companies in which they would like to work with. In short, if the government provides those without work with a mobile phone, they will be able to find themselves an occupation in order to live and survive.

Prompt.Prompt2: Explain the benefits of having Internet access on mobile phones for job seekers in the second paragraph.
Prompt.Prompt3: Provide some statistics or examples of how mobile phones have helped people find jobs in the third paragraph.
Prompt.Prompt4: Add a connecting paragraph that acknowledges the possible drawbacks or challenges of providing mobile phones to people without jobs.
Prompt.Prompt5: Write a paragraph to connect the left text and right text.

Outcome.Outcome1: Mobile phones are not only a device for communication and entertainment, but also a tool for accessing information and opportunities. for people who are unemployed and looking for work, having a mobile phone can be a great advantage. in this essay, we will discuss how mobile phones can help people without jobs in various ways, such as searching for vacancies, doing research, and contacting potential employers.
Outcome.Outcome2: Having internet access on mobile phones can be very beneficial for job seekers, especially those who are without work. internet access can enable them to access various online platforms and resources that can enhance their chances of finding employment. for instance, they can use the internet to update their resumes, learn new skills, network with potential employers, and apply for jobs online. internet access can also help them to stay informed about the latest trends and developments in their fields of interest. therefore, internet access on mobile phones can be a valuable tool for job seekers to improve their employability and livelihood.
Outcome.Outcome3: The benefits of mobile phones for job seekers are not merely hypothetical, but have been proven by various studies and reports. according to a survey by the pew research center, 28% of american adults have used a smartphone to look for a job, and half of them have filled out a job application using their phone. moreover, a study by the world bank found that mobile phones have increased employment and income for workers in developing countries, especially in sectors such as agriculture, trade, and services. for instance, in kenya, farmers use mobile phones to access market information, negotiate prices, and coordinate deliveries. thus, mobile phones can be a powerful tool for enhancing the employability and productivity of people without jobs.
Outcome.Outcome4: However, providing mobile phones to people without jobs may also entail some drawbacks or challenges that need to be considered. for instance, the cost of maintaining and using the mobile phones may be a burden for those who have limited income or savings. moreover, the availability and quality of the internet connection may vary depending on the location and service provider of the users. furthermore, the mobile phones may also expose the users to some risks such as cybercrime, fraud, or misinformation that may hinder their job search or harm their personal security. therefore, the government should also ensure that the mobile phones are accompanied by adequate support, education, and protection for the intended beneficiaries.
Outcome.Outcome5: Therefore, having a mobile phone can be a beneficial tool for those who are unemployed and looking for work. however, there are also some drawbacks that the government should consider before implementing this policy. for instance, (right text)
Outcome.Outcome6: However, there are also some drawbacks to this policy of providing mobile phones to the unemployed. one of them is the cost of maintaining the phones and the internet access. depending on the type and model of the phone, the monthly bills can be quite high, especially if the users are not careful with their data usage. this can add to the financial burden of the jobless, who may already have difficulties in paying for their basic needs. another downside is the potential distraction and addiction that the phones can cause. some people may spend more time on social media, games, or entertainment than on searching for jobs, thus wasting their precious time and resources. furthermore, some employers may not view mobile phones as a reliable or professional way of communication, and may prefer other methods such as email, fax, or face-to-face interviews. therefore, having a mobile phone may not necessarily guarantee a successful job hunt.

Context.Right: First, pets are our friends as well as certain human beings are. Similarly to friends, indeed, they are always with us and they are there if we feel alone. We can talk to them because they listen to us, more than some people will ever do. To illustrate this point, I can write about my own experience. When I was 14 years old, my uncle passed away and I felt like everything was no longer important. Talking to my friends was frustrating because none of them have ever felt that way. Since I was all alone at home for a long time, my dog was near me and it seemed to me that only him could understand my deeply feelings. Clearly, although pets aren't able to speak with us, we can nonetheless count on them.

Prompt.Prompt1: Write an introduction paragraph that states your thesis on the topic of pets as friends.
Prompt.Prompt2: Provide a general overview of the benefits of having pets as friends and how they can improve our well-being.
Prompt.Prompt3: Explain how pets can offer emotional support and companionship in difficult times, such as grief or loneliness.
Prompt.Prompt4: Add a connecting paragraph that makes the transition from emotional support to communication smooth. You can use a sentence like 'Another way that pets can be our friends is by listening to us when we need to talk.'

Outcome.Outcome1: Many people consider their pets as more than just animals, but as true friends who provide them with companionship, comfort, and support. pets can offer us a unique bond that is different from the one we have with other human beings, and they can enrich our lives in various ways. in this essay, i will argue that pets are our friends as well as certain human beings are, and i will provide some examples of how they can help us cope with loneliness, grief, and other challenges.
Outcome.Outcome2: Having pets as friends can be very beneficial for our well-being, especially when we face difficult situations or emotions. pets can provide us with companionship, comfort, and support, as well as unconditional love and acceptance. they can also help us cope with stress, loneliness, and grief, as they are sensitive to our moods and needs. as the left text shows, pets can be more understanding and attentive than some human friends, and they can make us feel less isolated and hopeless. the right text will further explain how pets can also improve our physical health and happiness by encouraging us to exercise, socialize, and have fun.
Outcome.Outcome3: Pets can offer emotional support and companionship in difficult times, such as grief or loneliness, because they can sense our emotions and provide comfort without judgment. unlike some human beings, who may not empathize with our situation or may offer unwanted advice or criticism, pets can simply be there for us and show us affection and loyalty. they can also distract us from our negative thoughts and feelings by engaging us in playful or relaxing activities, such as walking, playing, or cuddling. by doing so, they can help us cope with stress and sadness and improve our mood and well-being. therefore, pets can be our friends in a way that some people cannot.
Outcome.Outcome4: Another way that pets can be our friends is by listening to us when we need to talk. sometimes, we may not find the right words to express our feelings or thoughts to other people, or we may fear being judged or misunderstood. in such situations, pets can offer us a safe and comforting outlet for our emotions. they can also help us to relax and reduce our stress levels by providing us with physical contact and affection. furthermore, pets can enhance our communication skills by making us more attentive and responsive to their needs and signals.
Outcome.Outcome5: Another benefit of having pets is that they can improve our health and well-being. numerous studies have shown that pets can lower our blood pressure, reduce stress, enhance our mood, and boost our immunity. for example, stroking a cat or a dog can release oxytocin, a hormone that promotes bonding and relaxation. playing with a pet can also increase our physical activity and social interaction, which are essential for our mental and physical health. therefore, pets can be more than just companions; they can also be healers.
Outcome.Outcome6: Another reason why pets are beneficial for us is that they can improve our health and well-being. as many studies have shown, having a pet can lower our blood pressure, reduce our stress and anxiety, and increase our physical activity and social interaction. for example, walking a dog every day can help us burn calories, strengthen our muscles, and meet new people who share our love for animals. likewise, cuddling a cat can release oxytocin, a hormone that promotes relaxation and bonding. therefore, pets can not only be our friends, but also our helpers in maintaining a healthy and happy lifestyle.

Besides, dancing could show how civilization of that culture is. Moreover, people use dancing to entertain themselves. So dancing is important in every culture.

Prompt.Prompt1: Introduce the topic of dancing and culture in the first sentence and state your thesis statement.
Prompt.Prompt2: Provide some examples of different cultures that have distinctive dances and beliefs.
Prompt.Prompt3: Explain how dancing can reflect the values, traditions, and history of a culture.

Outcome.Outcome1: Dancing is a form of artistic expression that varies across different cultures and regions. it can reflect the beliefs, values, and traditions of a group of people, as well as their level of civilization and sophistication. in this essay, i will argue that dancing is an important part of culture because it represents the faith, the glory, and the joy of a culture. secondly, dancing can represent the civilization of that culture. for instance, i have seen many western movies that when a kingdom has a visitor from another kingdom, the king or queen would dance to show the splendor of their kingdom culture. the way of movement, the way that they costume, and also the music while they dance all demonstrate the civilization of their culture. in conclusion, i strongly agree with the notion that dancing is an important part of culture because dancing represents the belief of people. besides, dancing could show how civilized a culture is. moreover, people use dancing to entertain themselves. so dancing is important in every culture.
Outcome.Outcome2: Different cultures around the world have developed their own distinctive dances and beliefs that reflect their history, values and identity. for example, the maori people of new zealand perform the haka, a powerful and rhythmic dance that expresses their courage, pride and solidarity. the haka is often used as a challenge, a welcome or a celebration. another example is the flamenco, a passionate and expressive dance that originated from the gypsy culture of spain. the flamenco combines intricate footwork, graceful arm movements and vocal improvisation to convey a range of emotions, from joy to sorrow. a third example is the bhangra, a lively and energetic dance that originated from the punjab region of india and pakistan. the bhangra combines folk music, drum beats and colorful costumes to celebrate the harvest, weddings and festivals. these are just some of the many examples of how dancing is an important part of culture.
Outcome.Outcome3: Another reason why dancing is an important part of culture is that dancing can reflect the values, traditions, and history of a culture. through dancing, people can express their identity, emotions, and stories that are shaped by their cultural background. for example, some dances are performed as rituals to honor ancestors, gods, or nature, while others are used to celebrate festivals, seasons, or events. some dances are influenced by historical events, such as wars, migrations, or colonization, and show the resilience, adaptation, or resistance of the people. some dances are also inspired by the diversity, creativity, and exchange of ideas among different cultures. therefore, dancing can reveal the richness, complexity, and uniqueness of a culture.
Outcome.Outcome4: Secondly, dancing can represent to civilization of that culture. for instance, i have seen many western movies that when a kingdom have visitor from another kingdom, king or queen would dance to show a splendid of their kingdom culture. the way of movement, the way that they costume and also a music while they dance. all this is a civilization of their culture. another reason why dancing is important for culture is that it can be a form of entertainment and expression. in conclusion, i strongly agree with notion that dancing is an important part of culture because dancing are represent to believe of people. besides, dancing could show how civilization of that culture is. moreover, people use dancing to entertain themselves. so dancing is important in every culture.
Outcome.Outcome5: However, dancing is not only a way of expressing beliefs and showing civilization, but also a form of entertainment for people. many cultures have dances that are performed for fun, relaxation, socialization, or celebration. for example, salsa, tango, and hip-hop are popular dances that people enjoy in different parts of the world. dancing can also bring people together, as they share their skills, emotions, and stories through movement. therefore, dancing is a valuable part of culture that enriches human lives.
Outcome.Outcome6: However, dancing is not only a way of expressing beliefs and civilization, but also a form of entertainment for people. in many cultures, dancing is a source of joy, relaxation, and socialization. people dance to celebrate festivals, weddings, birthdays, and other occasions. they also dance to express their emotions, to relieve stress, and to have fun. dancing can also enhance people's health, fitness, and creativity. therefore, dancing is a valuable and enjoyable part of culture that people can benefit from in various ways.

Context.Left: The amount of money people earning sometimes is unfair. In a field of art, modern artist may receive high salary for their masterpiece creation while labors should be break their bone for years to get similar amount of money. Although some people view that government should be take a responsibility for this unfair situation, critics against such view. I agree that in this occasion the government is not granted to hand in.
Context.Right: Striking contrast, labor working in the merchandise factory receive coin of dollar even they make a hundred of 15 cm Buddha temples a day. In any case, a musician playing "I swear" several times receives different earnings that Padang got because the musician re-plays the song without any creation. Moreover, government cannot equalize the price of creation of modern artist because there is no certain parameter to value it, art value is about taste.

Prompt.Prompt1: Provide an example of a modern artist who earns a high salary for their masterpiece creation and explain why their work is valued so much.
Prompt.Prompt2: Compare and contrast the situation of the modern artist with that of the labor who works in the merchandise factory and makes a hundred of 15 cm Buddha temples a day.
Prompt.Prompt3: Discuss the challenges and limitations of the government's role in addressing the income inequality in the field of art and why you agree with the critics who oppose government intervention.
Prompt.Prompt4: Summarize your main points and restate your thesis statement in a different way. Provide a suggestion or a recommendation for the future.
Prompt.Prompt5: Write a paragraph to connect the left text and right text.
Prompt.Prompt6: Insert a passage connecting the two passages

Outcome.Outcome1: One example of a modern artist who earns a high salary for their masterpiece creation is damien hirst, a british artist who is known for his controversial and provocative works, such as a shark preserved in formaldehyde, a skull encrusted with diamonds, and a series of paintings made with butterfly wings. his work is valued so much because it challenges the conventional notions of art, beauty, and mortality, and because it attracts the attention and interest of wealthy collectors, museums, and critics who are willing to pay millions of dollars for his unique and original creations.
Outcome.Outcome2: The amount of money people earning sometimes is unfair. in a field of art, modern artist may receive high salary for their masterpiece creation while labors should be break their bone for years to get similar amount of money. although some people view that government should be take a responsibility for this unfair situation, critics against such view. i agree that in this occasion the government is not granted to hand in. a comparison between the situation of the modern artist and the labor who works in the merchandise factory illustrates this point. while the modern artist expresses his or her originality and creativity through a unique work of art that may appeal to a wide audience and earn a high price, the labor produces a hundred of 15 cm buddha temples a day that are identical and have a low value. the modern artist also enjoys more freedom and flexibility in his or her work, while the labor faces harsh and monotonous conditions. furthermore, the government cannot intervene in the market of art, which is based on subjective taste and preference, unlike the market of merchandise, which is regulated by supply and demand. therefore, the difference in income between the modern artist and the labor is not a matter of justice, but of nature.
Outcome.Outcome3: One of the challenges and limitations of the government's role in addressing the income inequality in the field of art is that it would interfere with the market forces that determine the demand and supply of artistic products and services. the government cannot impose a standard price or wage for different forms of art, as they are influenced by various factors such as originality, popularity, quality, rarity, and cultural significance. the government also cannot regulate the artistic expression and creativity of the artists, as they are protected by the freedom of speech and the right to intellectual property. therefore, i agree with the critics who oppose government intervention, as it would violate the principles of artistic autonomy and diversity, and potentially harm the innovation and development of the field of art.
Outcome.Outcome4: In conclusion, the amount of money people earn in different fields of art and labor is often unfair, but the government should not intervene in this situation. the value of artistic creation depends on the taste and appreciation of the audience, not on the effort or skill of the creator. the government cannot impose a standard or a regulation on something that is subjective and diverse. instead, the government should focus on improving the working conditions and the welfare of the laborers, who deserve more respect and recognition for their hard work. the government should also promote the cultural diversity and the creativity of the artists, who contribute to the enrichment and the expression of the society. by doing so, the government can foster a more balanced and harmonious environment for both art and labor.
Outcome.Outcome5: One reason why the government should not intervene in the income disparity between modern artists and laborers is that the nature of their work is different. modern artists produce original and creative works that reflect their personal expression and vision, and that appeal to a niche market of collectors and admirers. their income depends on the demand and appreciation of their art, which can vary widely and unpredictably. laborers, on the other hand, perform repetitive and standardized tasks that require physical effort and skill, but not much innovation or individuality. their income is determined by the supply and demand of their products, which are more common and predictable.
Outcome.Outcome6: One of the reasons why some people think that the government should intervene in the income gap between artists and laborers is the perception of effort and skill involved in their work. they might argue that a modern artist who produces a single painting or sculpture that sells for millions of dollars does not work as hard or as skillfully as a laborer who produces hundreds of physical goods a day. however, this argument ignores the fact that artistic creation is not only a matter of manual labor, but also of creativity, originality, and expression. furthermore, it overlooks the different markets and demands that influence the prices of artworks and commodities.

Outcome.Outcome1: Undoubtedly, the movement of modern forms of communication has changed better, which help people to interact to others, such as email and messaging without limitation time. i totally agree that using of these soft devices have cut much of time people need to see with their relatives. however, it is had some demerits on their social lives.

Outcome.Outcome3: Undoubtedly, the movement of modern forms of communication has changed better, which help people to interact with others, such as email and messaging without limitation time. i totally agree that using of these soft devices have cut much of time people need to see with their relatives. however, it has some demerits on their social lives.
Outcome.Outcome4: Undoubtedly, the movement of modern forms of communication has changed better, which help people to interact to others, such as email and messaging without limitation time. i totally agree that using of these soft devices have cut much of time people need to see with their relatives. however, it is had some demerits on their social lives. although email and messaging can facilitate quick and easy communication, they also have some drawbacks that affect the quality and depth of human relationships. another perspective, using of these facilities has influenced netizens to keep themselves becoming unsociable. it caused they were swept away by virtual atmosphere, so they do not do much social live interactions with others. the consequence of this case made some people become geek, as too much of using email and messaging, without direct contacts. however, people have had own minded to keep connection with their friends as a good relationship, meet them and talk by face to face directly. therefore, it is important to balance the use of modern forms of communication with the traditional ways of socializing, as both have their advantages and disadvantages. this way, people can enjoy the benefits of technology without losing the essence of human interaction.
Outcome.Outcome5: While email and messaging have some advantages in terms of convenience and efficiency, they also pose some challenges for maintaining a healthy social life. one of these challenges is that they can reduce the need and the opportunity for face-to-face communication, which is essential for building trust, empathy, and emotional bonds. moreover, they can also create a sense of detachment and isolation, as people may rely too much on virtual interactions and neglect their real-life relationships. therefore, it is important for people to balance their use of these modern forms of communication with other ways of staying in touch with their relatives and friends, such as phone calls, visits, or social gatherings. by doing so, they can enjoy the benefits of technology without compromising their social well-being.

Outcome.Outcome1: Hosting sports events can bring many benefits for the host city and country, not only in terms of economic development, tourism and infrastructure, but also in terms of cultural and diplomatic exchanges. the left text explains how sports events can foster mutual learning and respect among excellent athletes from different countries, who can showcase their skills and achievements while promoting the values of healthiness, honesty and fairness. the right text illustrates how sports events can enhance understanding, friendship and solidarity among nations, as the competitors demonstrate sportsmanship and cordiality after each match, regardless of the outcome. therefore, sports events can be a powerful tool for building bridges and reducing conflicts in the world.
Outcome.Outcome2: Hosting sports events can also bring significant benefits to the economy and tourism of the host city and country. by organizing such events, the host city can attract more visitors, investors and media attention, which can boost its reputation, infrastructure and income. moreover, the visitors can enjoy the diverse and unique attractions, cultures and cuisines of the host country, which can enhance its image and appeal. therefore, hosting sports events can be a way of promoting the host city and country as a desirable destination for both business and leisure.
Outcome.Outcome3: Hosting sports events not only brings economic and tourism benefits to the host city and country, but also offers cultural and diplomatic advantages that can foster international cooperation and harmony. by attracting visitors, investors and media attention, the host city and country can showcase their achievements, potentials and attractions, as well as address some of the challenges and issues they face. moreover, by providing a platform for dialogue, exchange and collaboration, the host city and country can enhance their reputation, influence and goodwill in the global community.
Outcome.Outcome4: Hosting sports events can bring many benefits to the host city and the participating countries, as well as to the athletes and the spectators. by competing and interacting with each other, the athletes can enhance their skills, achievements and sportsmanship, while the spectators can enjoy the excitement, diversity and harmony of different cultures. therefore, sports events can be seen as effective means of promoting physical, mental and social well-being, as well as fostering peace, cooperation and mutual respect among nations.
Outcome.Outcome5: Sports events are not only beneficial for the athletes, but also for the spectators and the host city. by watching the games, the spectators can enjoy the excitement, the skills and the sportsmanship of the competitors. they can also learn more about the history, the culture and the values of different countries and regions. the host city can showcase its attractions, its hospitality and its development to the visitors and the media. it can also boost its economy, its infrastructure and its reputation by hosting successful and memorable events. therefore, sports events can be a powerful tool for promoting cultural exchange, mutual respect and international cooperation.
Outcome.Outcome6: In addition to the benefits for the athletes themselves, sport events also have positive impacts on the host city and the spectators. hosting sport events can boost the local economy, tourism and infrastructure, as well as showcase the city's culture, history and attractions to the world. moreover, the spectators can enjoy watching the thrilling performances of the athletes, as well as learn more about the diverse backgrounds, traditions and values of the participants. therefore, sport events can foster a sense of pride, identity and belonging among the host community and the visitors.

Context.Right: To begin with, it is undeniable that education is better in big cities in comparison with countrysides. For instance, in my country the best schools, universities and institutes are located in cities, and todays education is one of the most important parts of our children's life. Therefore, it is a good idea for children to past their first earlier life in the cities.

Prompt.Prompt1: Provide some examples of the benefits of education in big cities, such as access to resources, opportunities, and diversity.
Prompt.Prompt2: Add a connecting paragraph that makes the transition from education to living standards smooth. You can use a phrase like 'Another aspect that favors living in big cities is the higher living standards that they offer.'
Prompt.Prompt3: Discuss how living standards are measured by factors such as income, health, and environment.
Prompt.Prompt4: Compare and contrast the living standards in big cities and countrysides, and support your argument with evidence and statistics.
Prompt.Prompt5: Write a paragraph to connect the left text and right text.
Prompt.Prompt6: Insert a passage connecting the two passages

Outcome.Outcome1: Education in big cities not only offers higher quality and variety of institutions, but also many other benefits for children's development and future prospects. for example, children in big cities can have access to more resources, such as libraries, museums, and technology, that can enrich their learning and curiosity. they can also have more opportunities to participate in extracurricular activities, internships, and competitions, that can enhance their skills and interests. moreover, they can interact with people from different backgrounds, cultures, and perspectives, that can broaden their horizons and foster their tolerance and respect. these advantages can prepare children for the challenges and opportunities of the modern world and give them a competitive edge in the global market. therefore, it is a good idea for children to past their first earlier life in the cities.
Outcome.Outcome2: Another aspect that favors living in big cities is the higher living standards that they offer. living in big cities means having access to better health care, public transportation, entertainment and cultural activities, and more job opportunities. these factors can enhance the quality of life and well-being of children and their families. moreover, living in big cities can expose children to more diversity and tolerance, which can broaden their horizons and perspectives. therefore, living in big cities can provide children with more advantages and opportunities than living in countrysides.
Outcome.Outcome3: Another factor that affects the quality of life in cities and countrysides is the living standard, which can be measured by various indicators such as income, health, and environment. generally speaking, people who live in cities tend to have higher incomes, better access to health care, and more opportunities for cultural and recreational activities than those who live in rural areas. however, living in cities also comes with some disadvantages, such as pollution, congestion, noise, and stress. on the other hand, people who live in countrysides may enjoy more natural resources, fresh air, and tranquility, but they may also face lower incomes, limited health services, and fewer educational and career options. therefore, the living standard is not necessarily higher or lower in cities or countrysides, but rather depends on the preferences and needs of each individual.
Outcome.Outcome4: However, education is not the only factor that affects the quality of life of children and their families. living standards in big cities and countrysides also differ significantly in terms of health, environment, culture and opportunities. according to the world health organization, urban areas tend to have higher levels of air pollution, noise, traffic and stress, which can negatively impact the physical and mental health of residents. on the other hand, rural areas often face challenges such as limited access to health care, sanitation, clean water and electricity, as well as higher rates of poverty, malnutrition and infectious diseases. furthermore, the cultural and social diversity of big cities can offer more exposure to different ideas, values and lifestyles, as well as more chances for entertainment, recreation and career development. in contrast, countrysides may have stronger bonds of community, tradition and identity, as well as more contact with nature and agriculture. therefore, the decision of where to raise children depends on the preferences, priorities and resources of each family.
Outcome.Outcome5: However, living in big cities also has some disadvantages that might affect children's development and well-being. for example, big cities are often crowded, noisy and polluted, which can cause stress, health problems and lack of natural environment for children. moreover, big cities can expose children to more social problems, such as crime, violence and inequality, which can harm their sense of security and morality. therefore, it is also important for children to experience the countryside, where they can enjoy more peace, fresh air and nature.
Outcome.Outcome6: However, living in big cities also has some disadvantages that might affect children's well-being and development. firstly, big cities are often crowded, noisy and polluted, which can cause stress, health problems and lack of natural environment for children to enjoy. secondly, big cities are more competitive and demanding, which can put pressure on children to perform well academically and socially, and reduce their time for leisure and hobbies. thirdly, big cities are more diverse and complex, which can expose children to different cultures, values and lifestyles, but also to potential conflicts, dangers and temptations. therefore, it is not always easy for children to adapt and cope with the challenges and opportunities of urban life.

Context.Left: First of all, a mistake does not last for a long time but a friendship lasts forever. Anybody does not remember mistakes. If someone remembers mistake, he or she has a closed mind. I want to say that mistakes will be forgotten quickly. For example, my friend Lee made a mistake that he broke my precious gift. However, I forgot about it just after two days, and I felt at peace with him. Some people might say I am silly, but I think mistake is more forgettable than friendship.
Context.Right: I think that a mistake can not brake friendship if it is not a big because friendship is forever and gift our life.

Prompt.Prompt1: The topic of the writing is how mistakes can affect friendship. The left text and the right text have different opinions on this topic.
Prompt.Prompt2: The left text argues that mistakes are not important and can be easily forgiven, while the right text implies that mistakes can break friendship if they are big. Explain why you agree or disagree with either of these views.
Prompt.Prompt3: Add a connecting paragraph that makes the transition from the left text to the right text smooth. You can use words like however, on the other hand, or in contrast to show the difference between the two perspectives.
Prompt.Prompt4: The right text is very short and vague. It does not explain what kind of mistakes are big enough to break friendship or why friendship is a gift for life. Elaborate on the right text by adding more details and reasons to make it more convincing.
Prompt.Prompt5: Write a paragraph to connect the left text and right text.
Prompt.Prompt6: Insert a passage connecting the two passages

Outcome.Outcome1: The left text argues that a mistake does not last for a long time but a friendship lasts forever, and that anyone who remembers a mistake has a closed mind. the author gives an example of how he or she forgave a friend who broke a precious gift and felt at peace with him or her. the left text implies that mistakes are minor and forgivable, and that friendship is more important and lasting than any mistake. the right text, on the other hand, suggests that a mistake can break friendship if it is big, and that friendship is a gift that enriches our life. the right text does not give any example of what constitutes a big mistake or how it can damage friendship, but it seems to imply that some mistakes are unacceptable and unforgivable, and that friendship is fragile and precious. the right text has a different perspective and a higher standard for friendship than the left text.
Outcome.Outcome2: Both the left text and the right text value friendship, but they have different opinions on how mistakes affect it. the left text argues that mistakes are not important and can be easily forgiven, because friendship lasts forever and nobody remembers them. the right text implies that mistakes can break friendship if they are big, because friendship is a gift that should not be wasted. i agree more with the right text, because i think that some mistakes are too serious to ignore or forget. for example, if a friend lied to me, betrayed me, or hurt me intentionally, i would not be able to trust or respect them anymore. i think that friendship requires honesty, loyalty, and care, and that big mistakes can damage these qualities. therefore, i believe that mistakes can not break friendship if they are small and sincere, but they can if they are big and harmful.
Outcome.Outcome3: However, not everyone agrees that a mistake is easily forgivable and friendship is more important than anything. some people might argue that a mistake can break friendship if it is a big one or if it shows disrespect, dishonesty, or betrayal. they might think that friendship is based on trust and loyalty, and that a mistake can damage or destroy these values. in contrast, the right text expresses this view and gives an example of a mistake that can ruin friendship.
Outcome.Outcome4: A mistake can not break friendship if it is not a big one, because friendship is forever and a gift for our life. but what kind of mistakes are big enough to ruin a friendship? i think it depends on the situation and the relationship between the friends. some mistakes may be serious, such as lying, betraying, or hurting someone intentionally. these mistakes can damage the trust and respect that are essential for a true friendship. other mistakes may be minor, such as forgetting a birthday, saying something rude, or breaking a gift. these mistakes can be forgiven and forgotten if the friends communicate honestly and sincerely. they can also learn from their mistakes and improve their friendship. friendship is a gift for our life because it gives us support, comfort, joy, and growth. it is more valuable and lasting than any material thing. that is why i agree with the left text that a mistake does not last for a long time but a friendship lasts forever.
Outcome.Outcome5: Therefore, i agree with the idea that a mistake cannot break friendship if it is not a big one. friendship is more valuable and lasting than any material thing or minor offense. of course, some mistakes are too serious or harmful to forgive easily, but most of the time, we can overcome them with understanding and communication. a good friend is someone who accepts us with our flaws and helps us to grow and improve. we should not let a small mistake ruin a long and meaningful friendship.
Outcome.Outcome6: Therefore, i agree with the idea that a mistake cannot break friendship if it is not a big one. friendship is more valuable and lasting than any material thing or minor offense. a true friend will forgive and understand, and not hold a grudge or resentment.
