Outcome.Outcome1: However, mobile phones not only facilitate communication, but also pose some serious challenges to children's social development. as i have explained above, using mobile phones excessively can impair children's face-to-face interaction skills, distract them from their academic tasks and expose them to violent and inappropriate games. these factors can affect children's emotional, cognitive and behavioural development and make them less empathetic, more isolated and more aggressive. therefore, it is important to limit and monitor children's mobile phone use and encourage them to engage in more positive and healthy activities. in the following paragraph, i will summarize my main arguments and draw a conclusion.
Outcome.Outcome2: These are some of the negative effects of mobile phone games on children's social skills. playing games on the phone can distract children from interacting with their peers, parents and teachers, and reduce their opportunities to develop social and emotional skills. moreover, some games can expose children to violent and aggressive content, which can influence their attitudes and behaviours. therefore, it is important to monitor and limit the use of mobile phone games by children, and encourage them to engage in more positive and meaningful activities.
Outcome.Outcome3: Mobile phone games can harm children's social skills in various ways. for example, playing violent games can reduce children's empathy and sensitivity to others' feelings and needs, as they become desensitized to the consequences of their actions. moreover, playing games can also distract children from engaging in face-to-face interactions with their peers and family, which are essential for developing social and emotional competencies. by spending too much time on games, children may miss out on opportunities to learn how to cooperate, communicate, and resolve conflicts with others. therefore, mobile phone games can impair children's ability to form healthy and meaningful relationships.
Outcome.Outcome4: These are some of the negative impacts that mobile phones can have on children's social development and well-being. mobile phones can distract children from their studies, expose them to inappropriate content, and encourage them to be more violent and less empathetic. my argument is that parents and educators should be more aware of these risks and monitor and limit the use of mobile phones by children. by doing so, they can help children to balance their online and offline activities, protect them from harmful influences, and foster their communication and social skills.
Outcome.Outcome5: These are some of the negative impacts that mobile phones can have on children's social development and mental health. while mobile phones can facilitate communication, they can also create barriers and conflicts among children and their families, peers and teachers. they can also expose children to harmful and addictive content that can influence their behaviour and attitudes. therefore, it is important to monitor and limit the use of mobile phones by children and to encourage them to engage in more positive and healthy activities.
Outcome.Outcome6: These are some of the negative impacts that mobile phones can have on children's social development and well-being. playing violent games on their phones can desensitize them to real-life violence and make them more prone to aggression and anger. moreover, spending too much time on their phones can reduce their face-to-face interactions and social skills, leading to isolation and loneliness. therefore, parents and educators should be aware of these risks and monitor their children's phone usage and behaviour. however, mobile phones are not only a source of problems, but also a useful tool for communication, as i will explain in the next paragraph.

Context.Left: Also, the more an advertisement of a product takes place in mass media, the more popular the product becomes. Advertisement is the most effective way to create a well-known product. Consumers tend to purchase the most known product when it comes to picking one out of two different brands of the same product. When a product is commonly used, it becomes trustworthy for the society, no matter what quality it is. However, it also has to be affordable for the consumer. Considering this fact, advertisements have undeniable affects on the society about the product being advertised. They make the product preferable.

Prompt.Prompt1: Define what mass media is and how it influences consumer behavior.
Prompt.Prompt2: Add a connecting paragraph that explains the relationship between product popularity and product quality.
Prompt.Prompt3: Discuss the possible drawbacks of advertisements for consumers and society.
Prompt.Prompt4: Summarize the main points of your argument and restate your thesis statement.
Prompt.Prompt5: Write a paragraph to connect the left text and right text.
Prompt.Prompt6: Insert a passage connecting the two passages

Outcome.Outcome1: Mass media refers to the various channels of communication that reach large audiences, such as television, radio, newspapers, magazines, and the internet. through mass media, advertisers can expose their products to millions of potential customers, who may be influenced by the messages, images, and appeals of the advertisements. by using mass media, advertisers can create awareness, interest, desire, and action for their products, as well as shape the opinions, attitudes, and values of the consumers. mass media can also create a sense of social validation, conformity, and popularity for the products, as consumers may want to fit in with the trends, norms, and expectations of their peers and society. therefore, mass media is a powerful tool for creating a well-known product that can attract and persuade consumers to buy it.
Outcome.Outcome2: Although advertisements can increase the popularity of a product, they cannot guarantee its quality. a product that is widely advertised may attract the attention of consumers, but it may also disappoint them if it does not meet their expectations or needs. therefore, product quality is another important factor that influences the consumer's decision making process. a product that has high quality can satisfy the consumer's demands, enhance the consumer's loyalty, and create a positive word-of-mouth effect. on the other hand, a product that has low quality can damage the consumer's trust, reduce the consumer's satisfaction, and generate a negative feedback loop. thus, product quality is an essential component of a product's success in the market.
Outcome.Outcome3: However, advertisements are not always beneficial for consumers and society. they can also have some drawbacks that may outweigh their advantages. for example, advertisements can create false or exaggerated claims about the product, misleading the consumers and creating unrealistic expectations. they can also manipulate the consumers' emotions and preferences, making them buy things they do not need or want. moreover, advertisements can increase the consumption of harmful or wasteful products, such as junk food, cigarettes, or plastic. this can have negative impacts on the health and well-being of the consumers and the environment. therefore, consumers and society should be critical and aware of the advertisements they encounter and not let them influence their decisions without rational thinking.
Outcome.Outcome4: In conclusion, advertisements play a crucial role in shaping the preferences and choices of consumers in the market. by exposing a product to a large audience through mass media, advertisements can increase its popularity and trustworthiness, regardless of its quality. this can give the product an edge over its competitors and influence the purchasing decisions of the consumers. therefore, advertisements are the most effective way to create a well-known product that can appeal to the society.
Outcome.Outcome5: Therefore, advertisement is not only a way of informing and persuading the potential buyers, but also a way of creating a favorable image and reputation for the product in the market. by exposing the product to a large audience through mass media, the advertisers can influence the consumers' perception and preference for the product. the more familiar and popular the product becomes, the more likely it is that the consumers will choose it over its competitors, regardless of its actual quality. however, the advertisers also have to consider the affordability of the product, as the consumers will not buy something that is beyond their budget. thus, advertisement is a powerful tool that can shape the consumer behavior and the demand for the product.
Outcome.Outcome6: Therefore, advertisement plays a crucial role in shaping the preferences and behaviors of the consumers in the market. by exposing the product to a large audience, it creates a sense of familiarity and recognition that influences the purchasing decisions. however, advertisement alone is not enough to ensure the success of the product. it also has to meet the expectations and needs of the consumers in terms of quality and price. otherwise, the consumers might be disappointed or dissatisfied with the product and switch to other alternatives.

Context.Left: "Capital punishment or the death penalty is a legal process whereby a person is put to death by the state as a punishment for a crime." In recently years, many countries have polished the law of the death penalty. In the whole world, 51% countries have polished death penalty; even, it is at 98% in Europe. Some people claim that without this punishment our lives would be less secure and crimes of violence would increase. However, others argue that it is not essential to control violence in society by the death penalty. Personally, I think it is no evidence about the reduction of crime rates due to the death penalty because of many reasons.
Context.Right: Secondly, nobody has the right to take another human life. It is undeniable that the rights of life are the basic and vital rights of a human being. No one has the right to take the life of a human; even if he committed murder. If you kill a criminal, you become a criminal. Moreover, if we think that killing is the best way to solve the problem, it is neither unethical nor immoral. In short, crimes seem to increase due to the capital punishment.

Prompt.Prompt1: Determine the topic based on the left text and the right text.
Prompt.Prompt2: The topic is the arguments against the death penalty.
Prompt.Prompt3: Elaborate on the statistical evidence or the logical flaws of the deterrence theory that supports the death penalty.
Prompt.Prompt4: Add a connecting paragraph that makes the transition from the first reason to the second reason smooth.
Prompt.Prompt5: Write a paragraph to connect the left text and right text.
Prompt.Prompt6: Insert a passage connecting the two passages

Outcome.Outcome1: One reason that i think the death penalty is not effective in reducing crime rates is that it does not address the root causes of violence and injustice in society. the death penalty may deter some potential offenders, but it does not prevent others from committing crimes due to poverty, inequality, mental illness, or other factors. furthermore, the death penalty does not offer any opportunity for rehabilitation, reparation, or reconciliation for the offenders and the victims.
Outcome.Outcome2: One of the reasons why the death penalty is not effective in reducing crime rates is that it does not deter potential offenders from committing violent acts. there is no clear evidence that the death penalty has a greater deterrent effect than other forms of punishment, such as life imprisonment. in fact, some studies have shown that the death penalty may actually increase the incidence of homicides by brutalizing the society and creating a culture of violence. furthermore, the death penalty is often applied in an arbitrary and discriminatory manner, depending on the race, class, gender, and location of the offender and the victim. this undermines the fairness and justice of the legal system and violates the principle of equality before the law. therefore, the death penalty is not a rational or humane response to crime.
Outcome.Outcome3: One of the main reasons that some people support the death penalty is the deterrence theory, which claims that the fear of being executed would prevent potential criminals from committing violent crimes. however, this theory is not supported by statistical evidence or logical reasoning. for example, according to amnesty international, there is no conclusive proof that the death penalty has a greater deterrent effect than other punishments, such as life imprisonment. in fact, some studies have shown that the death penalty may have the opposite effect, by brutalizing the society and increasing the level of violence. furthermore, the deterrence theory ignores the fact that many crimes are committed impulsively, under the influence of drugs or alcohol, or by mentally ill or irrational people, who are not likely to be deterred by the threat of death. therefore, the deterrence theory is not a valid argument for the death penalty.
Outcome.Outcome4: Another reason why i think the death penalty is not effective in reducing crime rates is that it violates the human dignity and rights of the offenders. the death penalty is not only a cruel and inhumane punishment, but also a violation of the most fundamental right of a human being: the right to life.
Outcome.Outcome5: One of the reasons why i think the death penalty is not effective in reducing crime rates is that it does not address the root causes of violence and injustice in society. the death penalty is a harsh and irreversible punishment that does not offer any opportunity for rehabilitation, reparation, or reconciliation. it also ignores the factors that may influence a person's criminal behavior, such as poverty, mental illness, abuse, or discrimination. instead of deterring crime, the death penalty may actually provoke more violence and resentment, as it creates a cycle of revenge and retaliation. therefore, i believe that the death penalty is not a solution, but a problem, for the society.
Outcome.Outcome6: One of the reasons why i think there is no evidence about the reduction of crime rates due to the death penalty is that it does not deter potential offenders. according to many studies, there is no clear and consistent correlation between the use of capital punishment and the level of violent crime in a country. in fact, some countries that have abolished the death penalty have lower crime rates than those that still practice it. furthermore, the death penalty may have the opposite effect of provoking more violence and revenge, especially in cases of wrongful convictions, miscarriages of justice, or discrimination. therefore, the death penalty is not an effective or fair way to prevent or punish crime.

Outcome.Outcome1: One of the benefits of living in the modern world is that we have access to a variety of food options that can suit different tastes, preferences, and occasions. by good food, we mean food that is not only delicious, but also nutritious, satisfying, and appropriate for the situation. good food can enhance our mood, health, and relationships, and it can also express our creativity, culture, and personality. therefore, it is important to be able to prepare good food, whether for ourselves or for others. however, preparing good food does not have to be a difficult or time-consuming task, as we will see in the following examples.
Outcome.Outcome2: One of the benefits of food that comes with instructions is that it can be healthy and tasty, without requiring much skill or time from the cook. there are many options of pre-packaged or frozen meals that are made with fresh and nutritious ingredients, such as vegetables, lean meats, whole grains, and spices. these meals can provide a balanced and satisfying diet, as well as a variety of flavors and cuisines. for example, a guy who wants to prepare a dinner for his girlfriend could choose a mediterranean chicken dish with roasted tomatoes, olives, and feta cheese, or a thai curry with coconut milk, vegetables, and rice. these meals can be easily heated in the oven or the microwave, and served with a simple salad or bread. by following the instructions, the cook can ensure that the food is cooked properly and safely, and that it retains its taste and texture. therefore, food that comes with instructions can be a convenient and enjoyable way to prepare a good food alone for some reason.
Outcome.Outcome3: Preparing a good food alone for some reason can be a way of showing care and affection to someone special. for instance, if a guy wants to prepare a dinner to his girlfriend, he could just buy some food that comes with instructions. normally you just need to put it into the oven and wait some time. by doing this, he can surprise her with a delicious and healthy meal, without having to spend hours in the kitchen or be a very good cook. he can also choose the food that she likes or that suits her dietary preferences, and create a romantic atmosphere with candles, music, or flowers. this can demonstrate that he pays attention to her needs and wants, and that he is willing to make an effort to please her. therefore, preparing a dinner to his girlfriend can be a simple but meaningful gesture of love and appreciation.
Outcome.Outcome4: To conclude, the development of technology has changed the way people cook and eat in many ways. it has made it possible to access a variety of recipes and ingredients from different cultures and cuisines, and to learn new skills and techniques through online platforms. it has also simplified the process of preparing food for those who do not have much time or experience, by offering ready-made or semi-prepared options that only require heating or minimal steps. therefore, technology has enhanced the enjoyment and convenience of cooking and eating, as well as the diversity and quality of food.
Outcome.Outcome5: One of the reasons why cooking skills are not as important as they used to be is the availability and variety of ready-made or semi-prepared foods that can be easily cooked at home. these foods can save time and effort for busy or inexperienced cooks, and still offer a satisfying and nutritious meal. moreover, these foods can also help people to impress their guests or partners with minimal hassle. for instance, a guy who wants to prepare a dinner to his girlfriend could just buy some food that comes with instructions. normally, he would just need to put it into the oven and wait some time. therefore, cooking skills are not as essential as they were in the past, when people had to rely more on their own knowledge and creativity to make good food.
Outcome.Outcome6: One of the reasons why cooking skills are not as essential as they used to be is the availability of convenient and varied options for buying food. nowadays, people can easily find different kinds of food in supermarkets, restaurants, or online platforms, that cater to their preferences, budgets, and dietary needs. whether they want to have a quick snack, a balanced meal, or a special treat, they can choose from a wide range of products and services that offer convenience and quality.

Outcome.Outcome1: One of the reasons why i think life in the old days brings more happiness to people than today is the relationships between people. in the old days, people had more opportunities to interact with their neighbors, relatives, and friends face to face. they shared joys and sorrows, helped each other in times of need, and celebrated festivals and events together. they formed strong bonds and a sense of community that enriched their lives. today, however, people are more isolated and distant from each other. they rely on social media and electronic devices to communicate, but often lack the depth and warmth of real conversations. they are busy with work and personal pursuits, but neglect the emotional and social needs of themselves and others. they are more likely to feel lonely, depressed, and alienated. therefore, the relationships between people today are more superficial and fragile than in the old days.
Outcome.Outcome2: One of the reasons why life in the old days brings more happiness to people than today is that people in the past had stronger social bonds and more care for each other. for example, they often visited their relatives and neighbors, shared their joys and sorrows, and helped each other in times of need. they also had more opportunities to participate in community activities, such as festivals, fairs, and ceremonies, which enriched their cultural and spiritual lives. they valued friendship, loyalty, and respect, and did not let materialism or individualism erode their relationships. therefore, people in the old days enjoyed more warmth and support from their social networks than people today.
Outcome.Outcome3: One of the reasons why i think life in the old days was happier is the quality of human relationships. people in the past had more time and opportunities to communicate with their families, friends and neighbors, and to share their joys and sorrows. they also had more respect and trust for each other, and less competition and stress. these factors contributed to their emotional well-being and sense of belonging. however, human relationships are not the only aspect that affects happiness. another important factor is the environment we live in, which has changed dramatically in the past decades.
Outcome.Outcome4: One of the reasons why i think life in the old days brings more happiness to people than today is the environment. the environment today is seriously damaged by human activities, such as industrialization, urbanization, and deforestation. these activities not only consume natural resources, but also produce waste, pollution, and greenhouse gases, which threaten the health and well-being of humans and other living beings. in contrast, the environment our grandparents lived in was more natural and harmonious. they could enjoy the beauty and diversity of nature, such as the blue sky, the green trees, the fresh air, and the spacious land. they could also interact with animals and plants, and appreciate the cycles and rhythms of life. living in such an environment, they were more likely to feel happy, peaceful, and grateful.
Outcome.Outcome5: One of the reasons why i think life in the old days brings more happiness to people than today is the pace of life. in the past, people had more time to enjoy their leisure, hobbies, family and friends. they did not have to face the stress and pressure of modern society, such as competition, deadlines, information overload and consumerism. they could appreciate the simple and natural things in life, such as reading, gardening, cooking and chatting. they did not have to rely on technology to entertain or communicate with others, but could use their creativity and imagination.
Outcome.Outcome6: One of the reasons why i think life in the old days brings more happiness to people than today is the quality of human relationships. in the past, people had more time and opportunities to interact with their families, friends and neighbors. they shared joys and sorrows, helped each other and enjoyed simple pleasures. they did not rely on electronic devices or social media to communicate, but rather on face-to-face conversations and gestures. they also had more respect and appreciation for their elders and traditions. in contrast, today many people are isolated, lonely and stressed. they have to compete and cope with the fast-paced and complex society. they often neglect or lose touch with their loved ones and communities. they also face more conflicts and misunderstandings due to cultural differences and lack of empathy. therefore, i believe that the human connections in the old days were more meaningful and satisfying than today.

Context.Right: Admittedly, reducing the proportion of violent content in TV shows could, to some degree, decrease the overall crime rate. However, in order to tackle this problem more effectively, governments must first prohibit any types of violent content in all childrens television programs. As a result of mental immaturity, most youngsters are incapable of distinguishing right from wrong. Little wonder, then, that by watching these violent TV programs and videos, juveniles will become very aggressive and offensive and have a great tendency to commit crimes. Therefore, it would be rather necessary for governments to establish an intensive law that prevents teenagers from watching these violent and brutal TV Shows and movies.

Prompt.Prompt1: Introduce the topic of violence in TV shows and its impact on crime rate in the first paragraph.
Prompt.Prompt2: Provide some statistics or evidence to support the claim that reducing violent content in TV shows could lower the crime rate.
Prompt.Prompt3: Add a connecting sentence at the end of the first paragraph that indicates the main argument of the essay, which is that banning violent content in children's TV programs is more effective than reducing it in general.

Outcome.Outcome1: Violence in tv shows is a controversial issue that has been widely debated in recent years. some people argue that exposing audiences to violent scenes can have negative effects on their behavior and increase the risk of criminal activities. others claim that violence in tv shows is merely a form of entertainment and has no significant influence on reality. in this essay, i will examine both sides of the argument and propose some possible solutions to reduce the harm of violence in tv shows on society.
Outcome.Outcome2: Reducing the proportion of violent content in tv shows could, to some degree, decrease the overall crime rate. this claim is supported by various studies that have found a correlation between exposure to media violence and aggressive behavior, attitudes, and emotions. for instance, a meta-analysis of 217 studies involving over 300,000 participants concluded that media violence exposure was associated with increased aggression, reduced empathy, and desensitization to real-life violence (anderson et al., 2010). moreover, a longitudinal study of 707 adolescents in the netherlands found that exposure to violent tv and video games predicted increased delinquency and violent behavior over a four-year period, even after controlling for other risk factors (hopf et al., 2008). however, in order to tackle this problem more effectively, governments must first prohibit any types of violent content in all childrens television programs.
Outcome.Outcome3: Admittedly, reducing the proportion of violent content in tv shows could, to some degree, decrease the overall crime rate. however, in order to tackle this problem more effectively, governments must first prohibit any types of violent content in all childrens television programs. as a result of mental immaturity, most youngsters are incapable of distinguishing right from wrong. little wonder, then, that by watching these violent tv programs and videos, juveniles will become very aggressive and offensive and have a great tendency to commit crimes. therefore, it would be rather necessary for governments to establish an intensive law that prevents teenagers from watching these violent and brutal tv shows and movies. this essay will argue that banning violent content in children's tv programs is more effective than simply reducing it in general, as it can protect the most vulnerable and impressionable group of viewers from harmful influences.
Outcome.Outcome4: The negative impact of violent tv shows on children is not only a matter of reducing the crime rate, but also a matter of shaping their personality and morality. children are more vulnerable to the influence of violent tv shows because they are still developing their cognitive, emotional, and social skills. they may imitate what they see on the screen without understanding the consequences or the moral implications of their actions. they may also become desensitized to violence and lose empathy for others who suffer. moreover, violent tv shows may distort their perception of reality and make them more fearful, insecure, and distrustful of the world. therefore, exposing children to violent tv shows could harm their psychological well-being and their moral development.
Outcome.Outcome5: Reducing the proportion of violent content in tv shows could, to some degree, decrease the overall crime rate, but this measure alone is not sufficient to address the root cause of the problem. the influence of violent media on young minds is particularly harmful and needs to be curbed by stricter regulations. as a result of mental immaturity, most youngsters are incapable of distinguishing right from wrong. little wonder, then, that by watching these violent tv programs and videos, juveniles will become very aggressive and offensive and have a great tendency to commit crimes. therefore, it would be rather necessary for governments to establish an intensive law that prevents teenagers from watching these violent and brutal tv shows and movies. such a law would protect the mental health and moral development of the younger generation and contribute to a safer and more peaceful society.
Outcome.Outcome6: Reducing the proportion of violent content in tv shows could have some positive effects on society, but it is not enough to address the root causes of crime. many studies have shown that the exposure to violence in the media can have a significant impact on the development and behavior of children and adolescents, who are more vulnerable and impressionable than adults. admittedly, reducing the proportion of violent content in tv shows could, to some degree, decrease the overall crime rate. however, in order to tackle this problem more effectively, governments must first prohibit any types of violent content in all childrens television programs.

Context.Left: Rather than passively forcing drivers to pay another fee, government should instead, be more active on advocating the use of more efficient and environmental-friendly energy or planning out more reasonable and convenient layout that allow people to reach their destinations with less oil. Sometimes traffic jam occur only due to the malfunction of a traffic light, or unreasonable organization of roadways. In these cases, the one who should be charged for a fine is the city planner, not drivers. Simply put, charging drivers fees regardless of the causes of the problems could be ridiculous and even unlawful.

Prompt.Prompt1: State your main argument and introduce the topic of congestion pricing.
Prompt.Prompt2: Provide some evidence or examples to support your claim that congestion pricing is not a fair or effective solution.
Prompt.Prompt3: Acknowledge the counterarguments or benefits of congestion pricing and explain why they are not convincing or sufficient.
Prompt.Prompt4: Propose some alternative solutions or policies that could address the problem of traffic congestion and environmental impact.
Prompt.Prompt5: Write a paragraph to connect the left text and right text.
Prompt.Prompt6: Insert a passage connecting the two passages

Outcome.Outcome1: One of the controversial policies that some cities have adopted or proposed to deal with traffic congestion is congestion pricing, which means charging drivers a fee for entering or using certain areas or roads during peak hours. the proponents of this policy claim that it can reduce traffic, pollution, and greenhouse gas emissions, as well as generate revenue for public transportation and infrastructure. however, this policy has also faced strong opposition from many drivers, who argue that it is unfair, ineffective, and burdensome. rather than passively forcing drivers to pay another fee, government should instead, be more active on advocating the use of more efficient and environmental-friendly energy or planning out more reasonable and convenient layout that allow people to reach their destinations with less oil. sometimes traffic jam occur only due to the malfunction of a traffic light, or unreasonable organization of roadways. in these cases, the one who should be charged for a fine is the city planner, not drivers. simply put, charging drivers fees regardless of the causes of the problems could be ridiculous and even unlawful.
Outcome.Outcome2: Congestion pricing, therefore, is not a fair or effective solution for reducing traffic congestion and pollution. it ignores the underlying causes of the problem and shifts the burden to drivers who may have no other choice but to use their cars. for example, some drivers may need to commute long distances to work or school, or to access essential services that are not available in their neighborhoods. others may have disabilities or special needs that make public transportation inaccessible or impractical. charging them extra fees would only increase their financial hardship and stress, without addressing the root causes of their travel needs. moreover, congestion pricing may have unintended consequences, such as encouraging drivers to avoid the tolls by using alternative routes that may be more congested, unsafe, or harmful to the environment. congestion pricing may also create inequities between different groups of drivers, such as low-income, rural, or minority drivers, who may be disproportionately affected by the fees.
Outcome.Outcome3: Some might argue that congestion pricing is a fair and effective way to reduce traffic congestion and pollution, as it makes drivers pay for the costs they impose on others and the environment. they might also claim that congestion pricing can generate revenue for public transport and infrastructure improvements, or that it can encourage drivers to switch to alternative modes of transport or travel at less busy times. however, these arguments are not convincing or sufficient for several reasons.
Outcome.Outcome4: While imposing congestion fees on drivers might seem like an easy way to reduce traffic and pollution, there are other ways that the government could tackle this issue more effectively and fairly. for example, the government could invest in public transportation systems that are reliable, affordable, and accessible, and that could reduce the reliance on private cars. alternatively, the government could promote the adoption of electric vehicles, hybrid cars, or other low-emission technologies, and provide incentives or subsidies for drivers who switch to them. furthermore, the government could implement smart traffic management systems that optimize the flow of traffic and reduce delays and accidents. these solutions could not only improve the mobility and quality of life of the citizens, but also protect the environment and enhance the sustainability of the city.
Outcome.Outcome5: Therefore, imposing congestion fees on drivers is not a fair or effective solution to reduce traffic problems and pollution. it would only burden the drivers who have no choice but to use their cars for work or other purposes, while ignoring the root causes of the traffic congestion and the environmental impact. the government should not simply shift the responsibility to the drivers, but rather take more proactive measures to improve the transportation system and the energy efficiency.
Outcome.Outcome6: To sum up, the argument that congestion fees can reduce traffic and pollution is not convincing, as it ignores the underlying causes of these issues and unfairly punishes drivers who may have no other choice. a more effective and fair approach would be to address the structural and systemic factors that contribute to inefficient and harmful transportation patterns. for example, (right text)

Outcome.Outcome1: One of the main differences between traditional school and home school is the learning environment that students experience. in traditional school, students attend classes with other peers and teachers in a physical setting, such as a classroom, a library, or a laboratory. they have the chance to interact with different people, share ideas, and participate in various activities. in home school, students study mostly by themselves or with their parents or tutors, using online resources, books, or other materials. they have more flexibility and independence, but less exposure to diverse perspectives and situations.
Outcome.Outcome2: Furthermore, there is an advantage of traditional school - socialization- establishes relationship with classmates. we can learn a lot from programs at home; however, our computers or televisions can't teach us how to get along with people. for example, students may learn how to cooperate with classmates from teamwork. studying alone at home might deprive us of these significant and valuable opportunities.
Outcome.Outcome3: Traditional school can also help students develop better academic skills and habits than home school. by attending classes regularly, students can follow a structured curriculum that covers the essential topics and skills for their grade level. they can also receive feedback and guidance from teachers who are trained and experienced in their subjects. moreover, students can benefit from the resources and facilities that schools provide, such as libraries, labs, and extracurricular activities. these can enrich their learning and stimulate their curiosity and creativity. home school, on the other hand, may not offer the same level of quality and diversity in education, and may depend on the parents' or tutors' ability and availability to teach and support the students.
Outcome.Outcome4: In conclusion, traditional school has many benefits that online learning cannot offer, such as socialization, cooperation, and interaction. while online learning may provide convenience and flexibility, it also isolates students from their peers and teachers, and limits their exposure to diverse perspectives and experiences. traditional school helps students develop essential skills and qualities that will prepare them for their future careers and lives. therefore, i believe that traditional school is better than online learning for most students.
Outcome.Outcome5: Therefore, traditional school has some benefits that online learning cannot provide, especially in terms of socialization. by attending school, students can interact with their classmates, make friends, and develop their communication and interpersonal skills. these skills are essential for their personal and professional growth, as well as for their mental and emotional well-being. online learning, on the other hand, may isolate students from their peers and limit their exposure to diverse perspectives and experiences.
Outcome.Outcome6: Therefore, traditional school not only provides academic knowledge, but also fosters social skills that are essential for personal and professional development. by interacting with classmates, teachers, and other members of the school community, students can learn how to communicate effectively, respect diversity, resolve conflicts, and build trust. these skills can help them adapt to different situations and challenges in the future.

Outcome.Outcome1: Moreover, you can also enjoy the beautiful nature when doing some outdoor activities like going hiking, sunbathing, going biking. these activities not only help you stay fit and healthy, but also enrich your senses and mood with the natural beauty around you. however, if you spend your spare time at home or something like that, you miss out on these advantages. spending time outdoors, people can breathe fresh air, feel the warm sun on their face and enjoy the complete peace that only nature brings.
Outcome.Outcome2: While staying at home or indoors may seem comfortable and convenient, it also has some disadvantages that can affect one's health and well-being. spending too much time indoors can lead to lack of physical exercise, which can cause obesity, cardiovascular problems, and low immunity. moreover, exposure to artificial light and noise can disrupt one's circadian rhythm, sleep quality, and mood. additionally, reduced social interaction can result in loneliness, isolation, and depression. therefore, it is important to balance one's indoor and outdoor activities and enjoy the benefits of both.
Outcome.Outcome3: However, spending time outdoors has more benefits than just relieving stress and boredom. moreover, you can also enjoy the beautiful nature when doing some outdoor activities like going hiking, sunbathing, going biking. if you spend your spare time at home or something like that, you can't enjoy beautiful nature. therefore, spending time outdoors is not only good for your health, but also for your happiness and well-being. spending time outdoors, people can breathe fresh air, feel the warm sun on their face and enjoy the complete peace that only nature brings.
Outcome.Outcome4: Spending time outdoors is not only beneficial for your physical and mental health, but also a great way to appreciate the beauty of nature. however, this does not mean that you should neglect your indoor activities, such as studying, working, or relaxing. you can balance your outdoor and indoor activities by planning ahead, setting priorities, and finding hobbies that suit your interests and abilities. for example, you can schedule some time every week to go hiking with your friends, but also reserve some time to finish your assignments or watch a movie. by doing so, you can enjoy the best of both worlds and enrich your life with different experiences.
Outcome.Outcome5: One of the benefits of spending your spare time outdoors is that you can also enjoy the beautiful nature when doing some outdoor activities like going hiking, sunbathing, going biking. these activities not only help you stay healthy and fit, but also allow you to appreciate the beauty and diversity of the natural world. spending time outdoors, people can breathe fresh air, feel the warm sun on their face and enjoy the complete peace that only nature brings. in contrast, if you spend your spare time at home or something like that, you can't enjoy beautiful nature. you may miss out on the opportunities to explore new places, see different animals and plants, and experience the changing seasons. therefore, spending your spare time outdoors can enrich your life and make you happier.
Outcome.Outcome6: Therefore, spending some outdoor time is not only beneficial for your physical and mental health, but also for your appreciation of the beauty of the world. instead of staying indoors and missing out on the wonders of nature, you can choose to explore different places and activities that can enrich your life and make you happier. you can find many opportunities to connect with nature and yourself, whether you prefer a relaxing or an adventurous way of enjoying the outdoors.

Context.Left: There are a lot of advances going on technology which are helping the environment a lot. One prime example is finding solutions to water problems in developing countries such as Africa. By pressurising sea water to produce vapour jets and filtering them through carbon nano tubes, we can get clean drinking water from sea water - an almost inexhaustible resource. Furthermore, Japan is working to build a working space solar power system by 23. By drawing on the colossal energy of the sun, it could meet the entire world's electricity requirements indefinitely without nuclear or GHG emissions. If successful, the impact on the world would be monumental. It would mean energy for schools, hospitals, and homes. It would mean another industrial revolution.

Prompt.Prompt1: Introduce the topic of how technology can help the environment in the first sentence.
Prompt.Prompt2: Explain how the sea water purification technology works and how it can benefit developing countries.
Prompt.Prompt3: Add a connecting paragraph that makes the transition from water problems to energy problems smooth. You can mention the challenges of conventional energy sources and the need for alternative solutions.
Prompt.Prompt4: Describe the space solar power system project and how it can harness the sun's energy. You can also cite some facts or statistics to support your claim.
Prompt.Prompt5: Write a paragraph to connect the left text and right text.
Prompt.Prompt6: Insert a passage connecting the two passages

Outcome.Outcome1: Technology can help the environment in many ways, from providing clean water to harnessing renewable energy. some of the most innovative and impactful projects are taking place in regions where environmental challenges are most acute, such as africa and japan. in africa, a new technique can turn sea water into fresh water by using vapour jets and carbon nano tubes, offering a potential solution to water scarcity and contamination. in japan, a ambitious plan is underway to build a space solar power system by 2030, which could capture the sun's energy and beam it back to earth, eliminating the need for fossil fuels or nuclear power. these examples show how technology can create positive change for the environment and humanity.
Outcome.Outcome2: One of the most pressing environmental issues facing the world today is the lack of access to clean and safe water for millions of people, especially in developing countries such as africa. water scarcity can lead to disease, poverty, conflict, and migration. however, a new technology could offer a solution by turning sea water into drinking water. the technology works by using high-pressure pumps to create vapour jets from sea water, which are then passed through tiny tubes made of carbon nanomaterials. the tubes act as filters, allowing only water molecules to pass through and leaving behind salt and other impurities. the result is fresh water that can be used for drinking, irrigation, sanitation, and other purposes. this technology could provide a sustainable and low-cost way of addressing the water crisis, as sea water is abundant and renewable, and the carbon nanotubes are durable and efficient. by harnessing this technology, developing countries could improve their living standards, health, and economic development.
Outcome.Outcome3: These are just some of the innovative ways that technology is addressing the water problems that plague many parts of the world. however, water is not the only scarce and vital resource that humanity needs to sustain itself. energy is another crucial factor that affects the quality of life, the development of economies, and the protection of the environment. yet, the conventional sources of energy, such as fossil fuels, coal, and nuclear, have many drawbacks. they are finite, expensive, polluting, and risky. they contribute to climate change, air pollution, and health problems. they also depend on geopolitical factors and create conflicts and inequalities. therefore, there is a pressing need for alternative solutions that can provide clean, abundant, and affordable energy for all. one of the most promising candidates is space solar power, which is the focus of an ambitious project by japan.
Outcome.Outcome4: These are just some of the examples of how technology is advancing to help the environment and solve global challenges. another ambitious project that could revolutionize the world's energy supply is the space solar power system that japan is working on. the idea is to launch giant satellites into orbit that can collect the sun's rays and beam them down to earth as microwaves or lasers. unlike terrestrial solar panels, the satellites would not be affected by weather, seasons, or nightfall. they could provide a constant and clean source of electricity for any region of the world. according to some estimates, a single satellite could generate enough power for 1 million homes, and a global network of satellites could meet the entire world's demand. this would reduce the reliance on fossil fuels, nuclear plants, and other polluting or risky sources of energy. it would also create new opportunities for economic development, innovation, and cooperation.
Outcome.Outcome5: These are just some of the examples of how technology is helping the environment and improving the quality of life for millions of people. however, there are also many challenges and risks involved in pursuing such ambitious projects. for instance, how can we ensure that the water purification technology is accessible and affordable for the communities that need it most? how can we avoid potential conflicts or sabotage over the space solar power system, which would require international cooperation and regulation? how can we balance the benefits of innovation with the ethical and social implications of transforming the natural world? technology can be a powerful tool for environmental protection and human development, but it also requires careful and responsible use.
Outcome.Outcome6: These are just some of the examples of how technology is transforming the environment for the better. however, not all technological innovations are equally beneficial or accessible to everyone. there are still many challenges and barriers that need to be overcome to ensure that the benefits of technology are shared fairly and sustainably. for instance, how can we ensure that the water purification technology is affordable and reliable for the communities that need it most? how can we prevent the space solar power system from becoming a source of conflict or domination by a few powerful countries? how can we balance the ethical and social implications of such radical changes to our energy and water systems? these are the questions that we need to address as we embrace the potential of technology to improve the environment.

Outcome.Outcome1: While some people believe that technology is the main cause of environmental problems and that humans should abandon it and live simply, others argue that technology can also be a source of environmental solutions and that humans should embrace it and innovate. the former view holds that technology creates pollution, wastes natural resources, and encourages consumerism and greed. the latter view contends that technology can provide clean energy, water, and other benefits for humanity and the planet. these are two contrasting perspectives on the role of technology in environmental sustainability.
Outcome.Outcome2: Both arguments present different views on the role of technology in saving the environment. the first argument claims that technology is harmful and that people should lead a simple way of life without using luxuries that damage the environment. the second argument claims that technology is beneficial and that it can provide solutions to environmental problems such as water scarcity and energy needs. however, both arguments have some strengths and weaknesses. the first argument has some merit in pointing out the negative impacts of overconsumption and wasteful use of technology on the environment, such as pollution, greenhouse gas emissions, and depletion of natural resources. however, it also ignores the positive impacts of technology on improving human well-being, health, education, and innovation. it also assumes that a simple way of life is feasible and desirable for all people, which may not be the case in reality. the second argument has some merit in highlighting the potential of technology to address environmental challenges and to create new opportunities for development and progress. however, it also overlooks the possible risks and limitations of technology, such as technical failures, ethical dilemmas, social inequalities, and unintended consequences. it also assumes that technology alone can solve the environmental problems, which may not be true without considering other factors such as political will, public awareness, and cultural values. therefore, neither argument is completely convincing or comprehensive. a more balanced and nuanced approach would be to acknowledge the trade-offs and complexities involved in the relationship between technology and the environment, and to seek ways to use technology wisely and responsibly for the benefit of both humans and nature.
Outcome.Outcome3: However, not everyone agrees that technology is the root cause of environmental problems or that abandoning it is the only solution. some proponents of technology point out that there are many innovations and developments that are actually beneficial for the environment and human well-being. they claim that technology can provide clean and renewable sources of energy, water, and food, as well as improve health, education, and communication. they cite some examples of how technology can solve some of the most pressing environmental and social challenges of the present and future.
Outcome.Outcome4: While some people say that technology is the main cause of environmental problems and advocate for a simpler way of life, others point out that technology can also provide solutions for some of the most pressing challenges facing the planet. both sides agree that the environment needs to be protected and that human activities have an impact on it, but they differ on the role and value of technology in achieving this goal. a balanced approach may be to recognize the benefits and drawbacks of technology and to use it wisely and responsibly, avoiding unnecessary waste and pollution and promoting innovation and efficiency. technology can be a tool for both harm and good, depending on how we use it and for what purpose.
Outcome.Outcome5: However, not everyone agrees that technology is the main cause of environmental problems or that abandoning it is the only solution. some people point out that technology can also be used to solve many of the challenges that humans face, such as water scarcity, energy crisis, and climate change. they cite examples of innovative technologies that are being developed or implemented to address these issues in sustainable and efficient ways. they believe that technology can be a positive force for the environment, if it is used wisely and responsibly.
Outcome.Outcome6: However, not everyone agrees with the view that technology is the main cause of environmental problems and that we should abandon it for a simpler way of life. on the contrary, some people believe that technology can also be a powerful tool for solving environmental challenges and improving the quality of life for millions of people around the world. they point to several examples of technological innovations that have the potential to address some of the most pressing issues facing humanity and the planet, such as water scarcity, energy security, and climate change.

Outcome.Outcome1: Although some people may argue that watching tv and movies can have some positive effects on children's social skills and cultural awareness, i believe that they can also have detrimental effects on their academic performance. tv and movies can distract children from their homework, reduce their attention span, and expose them to inappropriate or misleading information. therefore, i think that parents should limit and monitor their children's tv and movie consumption and encourage them to focus more on their studies.
Outcome.Outcome2: However, watching tv and movies excessively and indiscriminately can also have negative impacts on children's social development. for instance, children may become less interested in other activities that can enhance their creativity, communication, and cooperation skills, such as reading, playing, or joining clubs. moreover, children may be exposed to inappropriate or harmful contents that can influence their values, attitudes, and behaviors, such as violence, stereotypes, or consumerism. therefore, parents and teachers should monitor and guide children's tv and movie consumption and help them balance it with other forms of learning and entertainment.
Outcome.Outcome3: However, watching tv and movies for the sake of socialization has its own limitations and drawbacks. first of all, tv and movies are not always reliable sources of information and values, and they may expose children to inappropriate or harmful messages that could influence their attitudes and behaviors. for example, some tv shows and movies may glamorize violence, drugs, or sex, or stereotype certain groups of people, which could lead to children developing prejudices or misconceptions. second, watching tv and movies excessively could reduce children's opportunities and abilities to engage in other forms of social interaction, such as face-to-face communication, physical activities, or hobbies. these forms of interaction are essential for children to develop their social skills, emotional intelligence, and self-confidence, as well as to learn from others and express themselves. therefore, children should not rely on tv and movies as their main or only source of socialization, but rather balance their screen time with other more meaningful and diverse ways of interacting with their peers. for instance, they could join clubs, teams, or groups that share their interests or passions, or they could participate in community service, cultural events, or outdoor adventures that could enrich their experiences and perspectives.
Outcome.Outcome4: To sum up, i believe that children should watch tv and movies in moderation and under parental guidance, because too much exposure to these media can have negative effects on their academic performance, self-control, and moral values. my own experience as a child who wasted a lot of time watching tv instead of doing homework supports this argument. although watching tv and movies can also have some benefits for children's social skills and cultural knowledge, these advantages can be outweighed by the drawbacks if children are not selective and critical about what they are watching. therefore, my thesis statement is that children should watch tv and movies with limits and supervision. by doing so, they can enjoy the entertainment and education that these media offer, without compromising their development and well-being. this is a crucial issue that parents and educators should pay attention to, as tv and movies can have a lasting impact on children's lives.
Outcome.Outcome5: However, wasting time on tv is not the only problem that children may face when they watch tv and movies excessively. there are also some negative effects on their physical and mental health, as well as their moral development. for example, watching too much tv can cause eye strain, obesity, sleep deprivation, and attention deficit disorder. moreover, some tv programs and movies may expose children to inappropriate or harmful messages, such as violence, sex, drugs, racism, or consumerism. these messages can influence children's attitudes, values, and behaviors, and make them more aggressive, materialistic, or disrespectful. therefore, parents should monitor and limit their children's tv and movie viewing, and guide them to choose quality and educational programs.
Outcome.Outcome6: However, the negative effects of watching tv and movies for a long time are not limited to academic performance. there are also other aspects of children's development that could be harmed by excessive exposure to media. for example, watching tv and movies could influence children's values, attitudes, and behaviors in undesirable ways. depending on the quality and appropriateness of the programs, children could learn inaccurate or biased information, imitate violent or inappropriate actions, or develop unrealistic or unhealthy expectations. moreover, watching tv and movies could reduce children's physical activity, creativity, and social skills, as they spend less time playing, reading, or interacting with others. therefore, it is important for parents to monitor and limit the amount and content of tv and movies that their children watch.

Outcome.Outcome1: Animal extinction is a phenomenon that occurs when a species of animals disappears from the earth, either naturally or due to human activities. some people argue that animal extinction is not a priority issue for humanity, since there are many other pressing challenges that threaten our existence and well-being. they claim that we should focus on solving the problems that directly affect us, such as starvation, disease and wars, rather than spending our limited resources on saving animals that have no hope of survival. furthermore, human beings nowadays are still faced with many urgent problems such as starvation, disease and wars. when these problems are taken into account, extinction of some animals recedes greatly in importance and it is not sensible to devote our limited resources to animals that have been past help. we should put our own survival and sustainment in order first before considering the conservation of other species.
Outcome.Outcome2: Some people argue that animal conservation is not a worthwhile or realistic goal, given the many challenges and crises that human beings face in the world today. they claim that resources are scarce and should be allocated to more pressing issues, such as alleviating hunger, disease and wars, rather than spending them on saving animals that are doomed to disappear anyway. they contend that the extinction of some animals is a natural and inevitable process that cannot be reversed or prevented by human intervention, and that we should focus on our own survival and well-being instead of interfering with nature's course.
Outcome.Outcome3: However, animal conservation is not only a matter of sentimental or aesthetic value, but also a vital aspect of maintaining the health and diversity of our planet. animals play important roles in the ecological balance of different habitats, such as pollinating plants, dispersing seeds, controlling pests, and recycling nutrients. losing any species can have unpredictable and harmful consequences for the environment and the human well-being. moreover, animals are a valuable source of scientific knowledge and innovation, as they can provide insights into evolution, genetics, physiology, medicine, and behavior. many animals have unique adaptations and abilities that can inspire new technologies and solutions for human challenges. furthermore, animals are an integral part of the cultural diversity and heritage of many peoples, as they are symbols of identity, spirituality, and history. preserving animals can help us respect and appreciate the richness and diversity of life on earth.
Outcome.Outcome4: To conclude, this essay has argued that saving endangered animals is not as important as solving human problems, because animals have always been subject to natural selection and extinction, while humans have the responsibility and the ability to improve their own conditions. however, this does not mean that we should ignore the value and the role of animals in the ecosystem and in our culture. there are some ways that we can balance our needs and interests with those of other species, such as promoting environmental education, reducing overconsumption and pollution, supporting sustainable development and conservation projects, and respecting animal rights and welfare. by doing so, we can not only enhance our own survival and quality of life, but also preserve the diversity and beauty of nature for the future generations.
Outcome.Outcome5: However, some people might argue that preserving endangered animals is not only a moral duty, but also a way of maintaining the balance and diversity of nature. they might claim that every species has a unique role and value in the ecosystem, and that losing any of them could have unforeseen and detrimental consequences for the environment and human welfare. moreover, they might point out that many animals are endangered because of human activities, such as habitat destruction, poaching, pollution and climate change, and that we have a responsibility to mitigate the harm we have caused and to protect the natural heritage for future generations.
Outcome.Outcome6: However, not everyone agrees that preserving endangered animals is a worthwhile goal. some people argue that there are more pressing issues that demand our attention and resources. they claim that human beings nowadays are still faced with many urgent problems such as starvation, disease and wars. when these problems are taken into account, extinction of some animals recedes greatly in importance and it is not sensible to devote our limited resources to animals that have been past help. we should put our own survival and sustainment in order first before considering the conservation of other species.

Outcome.Outcome1: The topic of this document is the relationship between environmental protection and economic development. the left text argues that environmental protection is far more urgent than economic development, because earth is the only home for all the living creatures and its destruction would mean the end of everything. the right text uses an analogy of a man and his body to illustrate the importance of having a strong planet for the survival and well-being of all the living beings. the two texts share a similar perspective and emphasize the need to prioritize the preservation of the natural environment over the pursuit of material wealth.
Outcome.Outcome2: The relationship between environmental protection and economic development is a complex and controversial one. some people argue that economic development is essential for improving the living standards and well-being of human beings, and that environmental protection is a luxury that can be afforded only after achieving a certain level of wealth and stability. however, others contend that this view is shortsighted and irresponsible, and that environmental protection is far more urgent than economic development. they claim that all the living creatures live together on our mother earth and she is the only one. without earth, whatever great civil constructions and economic achievements will end up in vain because we will all perish as she's gone. just like a man that needs a healthy body, all the living creatures as a whole needs a strong planet as well. therefore, they advocate for a more balanced and sustainable approach that integrates environmental and economic goals and respects the natural limits and resources of our planet.
Outcome.Outcome3: First, environmental protection is far more urgent than economic development because the latter depends on the former. economic development cannot be sustained if the natural resources are depleted, the ecosystems are damaged, and the climate is destabilized. these environmental problems threaten not only the quality of life, but also the security and stability of the human society. moreover, environmental degradation often affects the most vulnerable and marginalized groups, such as the poor, the indigenous, and the women, who depend on the natural environment for their livelihoods and well-being. therefore, prioritizing environmental protection over economic development is not only a moral duty, but also a rational choice. all the living creatures live together on our mother earth and she is the only one. without earth, whatever great civil constructions and economic achievements will end up in vain because we will all perish as she's gone. just like a man that needs a healthy body, all the living creatures as a whole needs a strong planet as well.
Outcome.Outcome4: However, some people may argue that economic developments are more important than environmental protection. they may claim that economic growth can provide more resources, jobs, and opportunities for human well-being and progress. they may also point out that environmental protection can impose costs, regulations, and limitations on economic activities and innovation. they may believe that economic developments can solve or mitigate the environmental problems in the long run.
Outcome.Outcome5: Some people may argue that economic developments are more important than environmental protection, because they can improve human living standards and create more opportunities for growth and innovation. however, this argument ignores the fact that economic activities often have negative impacts on the environment, such as pollution, deforestation, climate change, and biodiversity loss. these impacts not only threaten the survival and well-being of other living creatures, but also undermine the long-term sustainability and resilience of our mother earth. the left text points out that environmental protection is far more urgent than economic developments, because earth is the only home we have and we cannot afford to lose her. the right text further illustrates this point by using an analogy of a man and his body. just as a man needs a healthy body to live and function, all the living creatures as a whole need a strong planet to thrive and coexist. therefore, we should not sacrifice environmental protection for short-term economic gains, but rather seek a balance between them that respects and preserves the natural resources and ecosystems that support life on earth.
Outcome.Outcome6: Some people may argue that economic developments are more important than environmental protection, because they can improve people's living standards, create more jobs, and generate more wealth. however, this argument ignores the fact that economic activities often have negative impacts on the environment, such as pollution, deforestation, climate change, and biodiversity loss. these impacts not only threaten the health and well-being of humans, but also of other living creatures that share the planet with us. therefore, environmental protection is far more urgent than economic developments. all the living creatures live together on our mother earth and she is the only one. without earth, whatever great civil constructions and economic achievements will end up in vain because we will all perish as she's gone. just like a man that needs a healthy body, all the living creatures as a whole needs a strong planet as well.

Outcome.Outcome1: One of the most debated issues in public health is whether smoking should be banned in public places or not. some people argue that smokers have the right to choose their lifestyle and enjoy their habit, while others contend that smoking infringes on the rights of non-smokers and exposes them to serious health risks. in this essay, i will argue that a total ban on public smoking is necessary and beneficial for the society, based on the following reasons. firstly, it is well known and clinically proven that smoking is extremely hazardous to the smoker and others who have been exposed to the fume over a period of time. recent death statistic released by the malaysian ministry of health shows that the top killer was lung related diseases caused by smoking. a large proportion of death involved second hand smoker particularly young children and pregnant women who were vulnerable to these lethal diseases. therefore, the number of fatality can be significantly reduced if a total ban on public smoking is implemented.
Outcome.Outcome2: Banning public smoking is not only a measure to protect the health of the smokers themselves, but also a way to safeguard the well-being of the public and the environment. by prohibiting smoking in public places, such as parks, restaurants, and offices, the exposure of non-smokers to the harmful effects of secondhand smoke can be minimized. this can prevent or reduce the risk of developing respiratory infections, asthma, allergies, and cancer among the passive smokers. moreover, banning public smoking can also reduce the environmental pollution caused by the discarded cigarette butts, ashes, and smoke. these can contaminate the soil, water, and air, and pose a threat to the wildlife and the ecosystem. therefore, banning public smoking can have positive impacts on the public health and the environment.
Outcome.Outcome3: Firstly, it is well known and clinically proven that smoking is extremely hazardous to the smoker and others who have been exposed to the fume over a period of time. recent death statistic released by the malaysian ministry of health shows that the top killer was lung related diseases caused by smoking. a large proportion of death involved second hand smoker particularly young children and pregnant women who were vulnerable to these lethal diseases. therefore, the number of fatality can be significantly reduced if a total ban on public smoking is implemented. secondly, banning public smoking can also benefit the society in terms of improving the air quality and reducing the health care costs. according to the world health organization, tobacco smoke contains more than 7,000 chemicals, many of which are toxic and carcinogenic, and can cause various respiratory and cardiovascular problems (who, 2020). moreover, smoking imposes a huge economic burden on the health system, as it increases the risk of hospitalization, medication, and disability (mackay et al., 2006). by prohibiting smoking in public places, the government can protect the public health and the environment, as well as save money and resources.
Outcome.Outcome4: However, some might argue that banning public smoking is an infringement of personal freedom and choice, or that it would harm the economy and the livelihood of tobacco farmers and sellers. these claims are not convincing because the right to smoke does not justify the harm and risk it imposes on others who have no choice but to breathe the polluted air. moreover, the economic and social costs of smoking-related illnesses and deaths are far greater than the benefits of the tobacco industry, which could be replaced by more sustainable and healthy alternatives.
Outcome.Outcome5: Smoking not only harms the smoker, but also endangers the health of those who are exposed to the smoke involuntarily. this is especially true for young children and pregnant women, who are more susceptible to lung related diseases that can be fatal. therefore, the number of fatality can be significantly reduced if a total ban on public smoking is implemented. however, some people may argue that banning smoking in public places is a violation of their personal freedom and choice, and that they have the right to enjoy their habit as long as they do not harm others directly. they may also claim that smoking has some benefits, such as relieving stress, enhancing concentration, or socializing with others.
Outcome.Outcome6: However, the health risks of smoking are not the only reason why public smoking should be prohibited. another argument in favor of a total ban is the environmental impact of cigarette waste and pollution. right text

Outcome.Outcome1: These are some of the reasons why i strongly support allocating more funds to education and prevention programs in the health sector. by investing in these areas, we can not only reduce the burden on the health system, but also improve the quality of life and well-being of the population. education and prevention can help people avoid or manage many chronic and communicable diseases, as well as promote healthy behaviors and lifestyles. therefore, i think that education and prevention should receive a greater budget than treatment.
Outcome.Outcome2: One way to demonstrate the benefits of education and prevention for health is to look at some successful examples from different countries. for instance, in finland, a comprehensive program of health education and prevention reduced the mortality rate from cardiovascular diseases by 80% in 30 years, saving thousands of lives and millions of euros in health care costs. similarly, in australia, a national campaign of skin cancer prevention and early detection reduced the incidence and mortality of melanoma, the most deadly form of skin cancer, by 50% in 20 years. these examples show that investing in education and prevention can have a significant impact on reducing the burden of disease and improving the quality of life of the population. in conclusion, a greater proportion of the budget should be allotted to education and prevention issues in comparison with treatment due to achieve more effective health system and greater level of well-being.
Outcome.Outcome3: To sum up, this essay has argued that education and prevention issues deserve more funding than treatment in the health sector. it has shown how investing in education and prevention can reduce the prevalence and severity of diseases, lower the costs and burdens on the health system, and enhance the quality of life and productivity of the population. these benefits outweigh the possible drawbacks of diverting resources from treatment, such as the ethical dilemmas, the uncertainty of outcomes, and the resistance from some stakeholders. therefore, the essay supports the view that education and prevention are more important and effective than treatment in addressing the health challenges of the society.
Outcome.Outcome4: The first reason why education and preventative measures should receive a greater budget is the potential improvements in health system. i believe that decreasing the number of patients in the health system can lead hospitals and healthcare centers to be managed effectively which will result in better treatments for current patients. therefore, society should be educated and became aware of health issues so that the potential precautions on the way of illnesses can be taken instead of trying to provide treatment for the increasing number of patients. moreover, education and prevention can also enhance the quality of life and well-being of individuals and communities by reducing the risks of chronic diseases, disabilities, and premature deaths. in conclusion, a greater proportion of the budget should be allotted to education and prevention issues in comparison with treatment due to achieve more effective health system and greater level of well-being. investing in education and prevention is not only a moral duty, but also a smart and sustainable strategy for the future of our society.
Outcome.Outcome5: One way to illustrate the benefits of education and prevention issues for the health system is to consider the economic impact of reducing the burden of diseases. according to the world health organization, investing in health promotion and disease prevention can generate significant returns for individuals, communities, and countries. for example, a study estimated that every us dollar spent on immunization programs in low- and middle-income countries could save 16 dollars in healthcare costs, lost wages, and lost productivity. moreover, preventing chronic diseases such as diabetes, cardiovascular diseases, and cancer can also lower the demand for expensive and complex treatments, and improve the quality of life and productivity of the population. thus, allocating more resources to education and prevention issues can not only enhance the health system, but also contribute to social and economic development.
Outcome.Outcome6: Educating people about health risks and how to avoid them can help them to adopt healthier lifestyles, such as exercising, eating well, and avoiding smoking and alcohol. these habits can reduce the chances of developing chronic diseases, such as diabetes, heart disease, and cancer, which can impair the quality of life and increase the burden on the health system.
